description:
Being a tourist in San Fran there are many choices for you to see and eat down by the water front . My son and I were walking along the front and stumbled into the Ferry building and came across to the San Francisco Fish Co. The menu for me was like a sea food candy store . So many choices to choose from. Crab Cake Sandwich, Shrimp Po Boy, Scallop Fish and Chips etc. 
We settled for the traditional fish and chips. For the price of $15 you get 6 nice size pieces of moist and the tastiest fried fish and chips I've ever had. Not knowing before hand what kind of fish we had eaten my son asked what kind of fish it was, our server said it was catfish. If I new that before hand I would have never order it because I had catfish once before and hated it. Thought it was gamely and very oily. So this was shocking to me. Even the chips (fries) were crisp, tasty and plentiful. 
I know there there are a lot of choices like I've said earlier but San Francisco Fish Co. would be the place I would " RUN" to the next time I'm in town.
author: Alan L.

description:
Got their seafood chowder and the gumbo. Both were meh but if I had to pick one, I prefer the gumbo. Not worth them being 6$ each- would not recommend getting. 

Got oysters and clams . $2 each. cherry stone Clams were good , fanny boy oysters were meatless and meh but i liked the blue point oysters - had a good briney taste and was meaty. delish. 

Tried their scallop which i made sure to ask it was dry and not wet [for those of you who care] and it tasted ok. Wasn't watery but the flavor was not amazing either. 

Also got the salmon and avo sushi roll. Rice was very mediocre..in general the roll was meh so prob wouldn't get again. If I was to come back, it would be for only the oysters/clams.  IMO the oysters taste better than the hog island ones.
author: Eva L.

description:
The dude at the front selling $2 oysters is a total scammer. I asked him for one of each oyster (there were 3 different kinds) and he gave me two of them. At first I thought it was because the third didn't fit on the plate so I ate the two and asked for the last one. He then acted like he already gave me the oysters. Then when I paid, I gave him a $20 and he only gave me $12 back even though they are only supposed to be $2 each (so $6 all together.) I told him he did not give me the correct change and he kept asking if I was sure and acting like it was my bad...

Basically he tried to give me 2 oysters for $4 each... hella shady. The oysters weren't even good or fresh. Also they were imported from the east coast-- not nearly as good as the west cost oysters from Hog Island. I would avoid at all cost unless you want to get scammed by unscrupulous people.
author: Jocelyn K.

description: I was looking for a little something to supplement another purchase I made at the Ferry Building.  Didn't quite find what I was looking for so I grabbed a cup of oyster gumbo.  I should have tried the raw oysters but now that I glimpsed another review, I'm glad that I didn't.  I got the impression this was just another commercialized food stall but I still enjoy coming to the Ferry Building and eating out back with the bay bridge in the background.
author: Maria K.

description: New favorite fish & chips. Tasty fish, and the batter is very light so you can taste the fish, and it doesn't hold a lot of oil. I took my order outside to watch the bay and the ferries on a beautiful November afternoon.
author: Herschell L.

description:
The Ferry Building is positively bursting with food stands, competition so fierce that serving delectable dishes is an absolute must to stay relevant. Luckily for us, San Francisco Fish fits the bill just right.

The establishment is small with only three tables for dining patrons. The menu is variable, not only offering typical lunch items, but also fresh oysters for $2 each and fresh cuts of various seafood. 

For our lunch, we ordered the fish and chips as well as a pint of New England clam chowder. The chowder was tasty with a strong aroma of herbs and fresh clams. Although, one complaint we would make is that the chowder did not have enough potatoes, eliciting a runnier texture than we would have liked. As for the fish and chips, it came out piping hot, a clear sign that it was made in house. The fries are cut on the smaller and thinner side, giving it crunchier bite, unlike the batter of the cod that veered towards the softer side. But at least the fish itself was tender. 

Prices are reasonable considering the area (this is SF after all!) and portion sizes are quite generous. Overall, San Francisco Fish is a decent spot for a quick lunch, earning a solid three stars from us.
author: Quyen L.

description:
I'm surprised this place doesn't have better reviews! We were here early on a Sunday and didn't want to wait on Hog Island to open so we opted for San Francisco Fish Company.

The highlights of our meal included the $2 raw bar (clams and oysters), the soft shell crab sandwich, and the fish from the fish and chips. 

That's right - $2 for raw oysters and clams. They were huge and super tasty. They are a little bit gritty, but not too bad. I highly recommend!

The soft shell crab was perfectly breaded (not too thick) with a fragrant crab taste in soft acme bread. The fish from the fish and chips was also lightly breaded and the filet was fluffy and flakey. 

I would 100% skip the clam chowder. That tasted so weird. It was not creamy and the flavors were funky. Definitely different from the clam chowders I had before.

I would come here if you want some good snacks in this area.
author: Karen F.

description: This place is affordable and delicious. This is the cheaper version of the sometimes overpriced seafood places by the water in San Francisco. I would say it is a place where you pick up the food and eat it outside by the water or in the common dining area by Peet's Coffee at the Ferry Building. Oysters at $2 a piece is value
author: Juan V.

description:
This crab sandwich didn't have a lot of filler, but it didn't have a lot of flavor either. And around $15 with tax and tip it's quite pricey considering it's not a sit down restaurant.

The oysters looked good, and seemed fresh on top of the ice. They were $2 each.

Also, they have a great take out menu for frozen seafood such as pasta that looked worth it.
author: Jack R.

description:
Came to the Ferry building and had the munchies.  Came across this little place and was very delighted to get 8 different style of oysters for $2 each.   They were great and I really enjoyed them.  

I'll have to come back and try some other stuff here.
author: Jesse L.

description:
I'm not sure why this place doesn't have a high rating. The fish n chips here is one of the best. It just melts in your mouth. Usually restaurants would use cod or haddock but the cashier told us they use some kind of a vietnamese fish.

The gumbo was also good, a bit on the spicy side. The fish katsu was nothing special but I like how hot and nice the rice was cooked.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Pretty fresh oysters and clams, cheaper than restaurants too! But location is for tourists... and they could at least washed the oysters and clams before serving... fish and chips and prawn burrito also pretty good too... would pick up some oysters and clam if i am passing by with tourists lol
author: Jason C.

description:
We were wondering in he ferry building trying to decide what to eat. Having skipped breakfast my tummy couldn't take it anymore. So we decided to just give this place a shot since it had some good choices. 
Well, turned out it was a great choice. We got the Salmon sandwich and the quarter sized seafood gumbo. I didn't taste the sandwich but I was told hat it was very flavorful and excellent. Gumbo was hot and spicy. Probably cleared my sinuses as well. Ha ha. It was just the right size for me served with oyster crackers and roux is pretty thick and tasty. We were lucky to be able to grab a couple of chairs in the store so we could sit down and enjoy our meal. They were also selling fresh oysters which seemed to be a popular hit with he crowd as well. 

Definitely is a great place to check out if you are in the ferry building and looking to satisfy your seafood craving.
author: Nish R.

description:
San Francisco Fish Company is located in the Ferry Building. It seems that they also sell butchered seafood but they have a pretty extensive menu. You order at the counter and hopefully can grab seating at the very limited counter/table. 

We came during lunch and it was really hot. It was also one of the few places with a short line. Kind of sad to say that the food was mediocre.
-CLAM STRIPS & CHIPS: The clam strips were really chewy and the amount of fries to clam strips is disproportionate. There's way too many fries in comparison. But they were both crispy which I appreciated. It also came with a wedge of lemon and tartar sauce.
-CRAB CAKE BURGER: The crab cake burger wasn't crispy. Maybe it was overly expectant of me. It was really soft as was the rest of the burger. It was basically a mouthful of soft and mushy food. I would've prefered some other textures.

All in all, I probably wouldn't return with all the other options in the building, though the food wasn't bad. Though I might consider coming back for the oysters though!
author: Mimi T.

description: Great stop in the Ferry building. We grab a raw oyster they shuck our front then inside grab the swordfish sandwich! Oh my that sandwich was really perfect! The fish was super fresh and the bun was soft and light with a little pesto and some romaine lettuce! Awesome job! Also had a little ahi poke which was flat and needed some flavor but decent quality. And he lobster bisque was not fishy.  All in all you had me at hello! Oh and grabbed a ice cold beer to wash it all down with! Delicious! And check out their to go offerings they look amazing too!
author: Kristen N.

description:
I tried San Francisco Fish Company for lunch a couple of days ago. It is located in the Ferry building so at the peak lunch hour like every other place it is pretty full. San Francisco Fish Company is part fish market and part deli where you can get staples like fish and chips, clam chowder and various sandwiches. It has around 6-8 high chair types seats on the left but it is essentially a to-go place. After going through the menu I decided to get the Soft Shell Crab Sandwich ($12) as I had not had Soft Shell Crab in a long time. After ordering it was a 10 minute wait and I was on my way.

The Soft Shell Crab Sandwich was undoubtedly very good. It had a perfectly fried soft shell crab on a soft bun with a leaf of lettuce and some dressing. It was minimalistic but good kind of way. The only complaint was that this was just a snack size portion. Price wise it was not very high for seafood and the location. Most of the other items on the menu are also all around the $15 mark, so it's not bad for a light meal. Generous 3.5 stars rounded up to 4 is how I'd rate this place.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Had a great tuna burger here. The clam strips and fries were good as well. Quick and delicious option if you are in the area and crave some seafood. I would definitely come back to try some of the other interesting options I saw on their menu.
author: Ranny H.

description:
Food 3/5. Service 4/5. Ambiance 3/5.

There's is two main places to get oysters at the ferry building. There is this place and hog island oysters. Hog island oysters is far superior but if you ever want quick and fast oysters this is the best place to do so. 

In the hustle and bustle of the ferry building, they sell oysters out of ice trays. They usually have three oysters to choose from. This time I decided to try the Bluepoint oysters. The oysters didn't seem to be shucked very well. However, with horse radish, cocktail sauce and lemon it was just as good. 

Overall, it's a great spot for quick and easy oysters.

Tips - They take cash and credit card so don't worry! 

Pros - Quick and fast! 

Cons - Gets a little hectic with so many people walking by in the ferry building.
author: Brian N.

description: Im walking through the ferry building and I stopped here for 5 minutes trying to get the workers to acknowledge me so I can buy some oysters but instead they rudely turn the cheek and continue with their tasks.
author: Barry Bongs M.

description: Best fish and chips! This little shop inside the ferry building is a great find! The fish was fresh and the fries were crispy. They have a large menu, it was hard to pick what I wanted but I was so happy with my choice.
author: Sarah F.

description:
The fresh oysters and clams here are always delicious. It'd be nice if they ask customers who take 10 minutes to order while there's a long line behind them to step aside.

We also ordered the oyster po boy sandwich and fish 'n chips. Both delicious, and so fresh. A bit pricey, though, at $14 each, considering the quantity.
author: Bernardette O.

description:
My boyfriend from SoCal came to NorCal craving a clam chowder bread bowl so I brought him to the SF Fish Company and satisfied his clam chowder bread bowl craving... along with garlicy saucy steamed mussels, crispy light fish n chips, juicy tasty oysters, and an ice cold beer. Now THAT is how you eat in SF.

This place is fantastic. A little bit expensive - our bill definitely added up - but totally worth it if you're looking for good fresh seafood.

There's very limited seating, but nice areas to sit outside of the ferry building, near the water. That's the best way to enjoy seafood anyways :)
author: Monica H.

description:
OMG this is place is amazing! Three reasons:

1. Oysters!! They have $2 oysters daily, clams on most days tho I usually stick to the oysters. And it changes up! So each day you can try a new locale. Yum! 

2. Nice array of prepared seafood delights in their deli counter, faves include Ahi tuna poke, lomi lomi and an interesting tea infused smoked scallop.

3. They're super nice! They also have a Happy Hour deal for a half dozen oysters and a beer. You really can't go wrong
author: Victoria C.

description: Fish Tacos are awesome! Prawn sandwich a little dry. Prompt service and budget friendly ferry building eatery!
author: Sara S.

description:
I want to say I'm a fan of how fresh the seafood is here. I got a crab quesadilla $14. It's pretty bland. The guac that came with the order made the difference in taste. There was plenty of crab in the quesadilla, which I liked, but I would also prefer some sort of flavoring. Even the cheese was kind of meh. I also tried their fish and chips. I have to say, the fish was really good. It was cooked to perfection and it was soft.

Staff here is friendly. There are about 6-8 seats available by the store. I'm interested in coming back to try their sushi. Seems decently priced, $11 for a specialty roll.
author: Benita M.

description: This place is a hidden SF gem! A great place to get fresh seafood and meals before a Giants game at ATT. Sole sandwiches and gumbo are excellent!
author: Stephen B.

description:
One of our favorite places to grab lunch at the Ferry Building when we are pressed with time. 
Every time we all go in different directions to grab something and end up converging at San Francisco Fish Company.

This is a small grab-n-go place which is always filled with the buzzing lunch-time crowd of the ferry building.

Its reasonably priced, their sushi is consistently good. Get their Fish n chips, wait until they cool down a lil bit (unless you wanna risk burning your mouth) dunk the fish in tartar sauce and you'll see heaven. I haven't tried their oysters yet, but sure will on my next trip to SF.

Must try!
author: Sujeesha V.

description:
$2 freshly shucked oysters? Yes! Best deal you can probably get in the city for the quality provided.

I went on Friday and caught their Aloha Friday Deals and got to order the lobster chowder and shrimp tacos. Shrimp was juicy, but the tacos overall needed a little bit more flavor. I also ordered a deep fried oyster po'boy which if you love fried oysters I recommend you get! I didn't get a chance to try their poke bowls, but I would order that next time.
author: Mila J.

description:
I had a soft shell crab sandwich the other day, and I've got to say it was absolutely delicious.  T-God for my good intuition on a rain Friday, because this crab sandwich was not only worth the deal, (12 spanking dollars, people!!) but it also was mouthwatering delicious.  Large portions of crab - like the kind where it's an actual crab in the sandwich - the didn't even take apart the meat.  I think because of this, the crab's freshness was maintained and you can taste the sea in it!  Agh, can't rave enough about it!

I didn't get to try it, but the oysters they were selling looked BOMB as well.  That's next on my list!

Because it is the Ferry Building, I'd say it will always be pretty packed for lunch.  This is also a difficult place to find seating, especially if you're meeting someone, so that might be a bad option.  However, food-wise, there is so much variety!

I can also attest to the snobbish attitude I received from the employees there; I simply asked what they would recommend from the menu, yet all I got was "I don't eat seafood" and a face that made me question my own question.  Customer service needs to step it up! 

But overall, I'm definitely a fan and would probably up this numerical value to a 4.5 if I could.  Good deal, good food, good location!  Keep it up! :)
author: Jana L.

description: Love the fish and chips! Food was hot and service was friendly and fast! Recommend! You won't be sorry!
author: Livernonions P.

description: One word... fish & chips!  Love it!  So light and fluffy and crispy too.  Check out pictures.
author: David S.

description: They serve sandwiches that make your mouth water. Anything with crab is sublime: breakfast burrito with crab, crab cake sandwich, crab quesadilla. The only reason it's not 5 stars is because of the pricing. Most sandwiches are around $15 for what is basically an appetizer portion. But in exchange for the big price tag you get some of the best seafood sandwiches anywhere.
author: Carl W.

description: Chose this place because Hog Island was packed and I wanted fresh food. They had a display of $2 oysters on the table in front of the shop, so I was immediately sucked in. I went with the oysters! The man offered me 2 choices, so I bought 4 of each type. They were fat! Tons of meat for the money. The customer service was not the friendliest unfortunately. Also, they might have received another star if they offered crackers or bread with the oysters. I'm not sure I would come back given all the other options
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Fresh, fresh oysters and clams! Only $2 each and already shucked. You just walk by the stand and pick whichever ones you want and they just hand it to you right from their stand. I tried the Fanny Bay Oyster today and it was fresh and sweet. They also have toppings such as lemon juice, horseradish, and cocktail sauce. It's the perfect place for a quick, light bite on-the-go.
author: Annie N.

description:
While checking out all the eateries in the Ferry Building - I decided to give the San Francisco Fish Company a try.  There was a crowd gathered for the oysters, so I figured that was a good sign.  I ordered the Shrimp Tacos and my friend had the Fish & Chips.  The food was reasonable priced and we topped it off with a few brews.  the food was so fresh and they provided good portions.  

I recommend this spot - if the lines aren't too long - get your grub on!
author: Shane J.

description: Simple and good. I was searching for fish & chips close and I found it. The staff was nice. It was inside the Embarcadero market. There were a few tables to sit at to eat if you wanted. The portion was plenty. The rest of the menu had soups like clam chowder or salmon chowder, various fish sandwiches. Everything looked good. I would return.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Slave girl and I were trying to find random food and we saw the stand with 2 type of oysters and 1 clam. Slave girl wasn't in the mood for oysters and I wasn't in the mood to wait in line for hog island, so I decided to give this place a try. 

At $2 a piece, it's not the cheapest oysters around. It tasted fresh but for paying $2 for it, I really would like to see the shuckling process since I had no idea how long the oysters and clams had been sitting out under the sun light with dust around.

The service was normal. Not amazing friendly but not rude either.

I also walked in to see their fish stock. They had some good selections but the price was definitely tourist price, which defeat the purpose of buying from source. 

For a quick seafood fix, I would say this place still a go.
author: Fan H.

description:
Fresh fish, decent prices. My first restaurant to try in the Ferry Building. I didn't have much time to sit down and eat before the Giants game this morning. The clam chowder was okay, tasted better elsewhere but my Sea Bass sandwich with Chimichurri (sp?) was good. Fresh fried sea bass, chimichurri sauce, lettuce and a soft roll. Excellent. Ahi Tuna Poke was on par with other places i've tried. 

If you're looking for fresh seafood and fresh oysters, check out the SF Fish Co. Good stuff.
author: Ticha B.

description: This place was more of a disappointment than the many typical tourist shops out there. The two stars was for the fresh oysters and clams which were $2 each.  The disappointment was the $15 crab burrito which was as small as a breakfast burrito from McDonalds. It consist of 70% egg and 10% crab and 20% green onions/guac. Not only was it oily but it tastes like something you can put together at home. I'd been much happier with the fish and chips.
author: Alan P.

description:
Everytime I head out to the Ferry Building, I just can't help but to stop here to pick up some freshly shucked oysters and clams.  They set up a table right up front along the walkway as you drool walking on by.  

They are relatively cheap...around $2 each.  They switch up their oysters so it really depends on what they have that day.  They also have all the fixins...horseradish, cocktail sauce, tabasco, and lemon to dress up your seafood.  

Last time I was there, I saw someone order fish and chips which looked amazing!  I'm going to have to try that the next time I come by.
author: Jen W.

description: We stopped by the market and were looking for a snack to try. We were enticed by the seafood selection and noticed there was a soft shell crab po'boy sandwich on the menu for $14. We decided to try that and I was not disappointed. The crab was deep fried and crunchy with a mayo style sauce. The bun was warm and moist. The sandwich also came with a side of coleslaw.
author: Angela M.

description:
The worst clam chowder ever! After two bites of trying to gag it down I said something and was treated with extreme rudeness. 

Too many other good places in the area. Don't waste your time here.
author: K C.

description:
The attitude on the cashier here really irked me something serious.  

me: Could I get the New England clam chowder?
cashier: Nope!

An explanation would have been nice, but that guy seriously did not want to be there.  The whole place was more or less of a mess at 3pm on a Saturday afternoon.  They still had 3 hours to closing, but I guess they weren't making any more soup.  Anyways I ended up ordering the Manhattan style chowder which I was okay with too since I don't see it often.  It came out to $9 for a pint.  My friend's ordered bread bowls.  It was weird that they don't put the soup in your bread bowl but just give it to you separately...

Upon trying to pay, I tried using Apple Pay.  I didn't think it went through but the cashier said it did so I left it at that and walked away.  I explicitly asked him too because I didn't think it actually worked.  A couple minutes later, he comes to tell me that it didn't work, as I thought. So I go back there to pay, already fed up with this place.

Manhattan Clam Chowder:
Not much clams to be honest.  Mostly potatoes and pepper.  I wouldn't say it's anything special here.  

Gumbo: 
Super thick.  Not a gumbo at all.  Tasted like refried beans more than gumbo.  It was hardly edible.

This spot is more of a tourist trap in the Ferry Building.  There are a lot of other more reputable businesses here that you should go to instead of this sorry place.  The only reason I might come back here for is that they seem to serve Hawaiian food on certain days of the week.
author: Bryson L.

description: Great place ! Love the location of the Fairy market and their fish tacos were great. The tacos were surrounded by a nice tortilla, one that wasn't to hard or soft.  I would recommend using a little bit less sauce, since the tortilla began to break on one of my tacos. Overall, this was a great place!  Would recommend.
author: Dylan L.

description: Got a little bit of everything!! Ahi tuna salad. New England clam chowder and a crab Louie salad! Deelish
author: Monica B.

description:
$2 oysters! Found this place by mistake, was walking through the ferry building, saw a table selling oysters with $2 sign. I'm not sure of this is their happy hour prices but it was Friday around 5 or 6ish in the evening. 

He was offering 2 types oysters and clams. We order 2 of each. Cocktail sauce, lemon, horse radish set out on the side to put onto your oysters. The man wasn't very friendly with us or other customers. This place isn't very fancy, looked more like a seafood area in a grocery but with some high table tops. Don't except fancy silverware, just paper plates, and plastic utensils. But the oysters and clams were pretty good and fresh. 

I'm giving 3 stars because the man selling the oysters wasn't very friendly, wish they had silverware or plastic silver wear set out. Other than that if you looking for cheap oysters while in the ferry building and you don't want to spend a lot at hog island come here!
author: Cecilia P.

description: For a $14 crab cake sandwich I expect to taste real crab, but unfortunately most of the taste is from the bread filling and there is barely any crab visible in the patty. Don't get the crab cake sandwich unless you want to waste your money. The clam chowder was ok but could have used more clams.
author: Andy Z.

description: Took advantage of happy hour special while waiting to board the ferry back to Vallejo. Half dozen oysters and a pint for $16. Oysters were great. First time I had Scrimshaw, refreshing. This will be a stop I make often. :)
author: Felicia M.

description:
This review is strictly for their sushi.

There's a lady who drops by between 11:30a-Noon to drop off sushi. Their sushi comes from a different vendor, so it's not prepared on site. I came in today around 11:30 to grab some before I headed back to my office but the lady hasn't swung by yet. The guy behind the counter said she's running late so I decided to stick around. Once I sat down, the guy handed me a cup of water while I waited! which was really sweet of him. 10 mins later, another guy with glasses came by to let me know that she's still running late and didn't want me to be late for work just in case if had something inportant to do haha. Which was really considerate and nice of them.

The folks that work here are really nice and as well as the lady who drops off the sushi. I had asked her if they had a restaurant in the city and they don't! (to my surprise!) but they plan on opening one next year, I guess. 

If you're in the mood for hella fresh sushi and chill vibes, try this spot! just come around noon to beat the crowd. They have a great selection of sushi assortments to choose from!
author: Robin M.

description:
San Francisco Fish Companies offers fresh caught seafood and edible fish/seafood entress.

menu: lobster bisque, sammies, po boys, breakfast burritos, fish & chip, fish tacos, raw clams/oysters.

eats: raw clam/oyster 2@
-cherrystone clam- chewy, small, not a lot of taste
-blue point-fat, chubby, slightly cold 
--fatty boy? succulent, also slight refrigerated coldness
good value, choice of cocktail sauce, atomic horseradish, tabasco sauce....

take outs:
-fish & chip 3 pieces of fish stick looking quality, didn't ask.
-lobster bisque (6) passed also, chinese ladies seem to be enjoying it.
author: Victor G.

description:
Location: Conveniently located in the ferry building it's very easy to find. It's a small shop so you definitely need to get there early to beat the lunch rush since it can get pretty long. If you're not willing to get a hot dish they have plenty of things that are premade in the fridge or things you can buy for later. 

What to get: 
- Soft shell crab po' boy - big fan of this one! Freshly fried crab on good bread is definitely a combo you can't beat. Well worth a try if you haven't done so yet. 

- coconut shrimp - It was good, but nothing too special. I thought it was overfried and was a bit hard to eat. They pair it with fries so overall it's a filling meal during the lunch rush. 

Overall, if you're in the mood for decently priced seafood in SF, this is a good option.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Mmm Fridays are Aloha Fridays at the San Francisco Fish Company! The Ferry Building is buzzing with people on Fridays at lunchtime, but I was determined to try their Aloha Friday menu. I immediately knew I wanted the scallops and fries. Not too long after, it came out steaming hot, and I told myself to waaaaiiiit for the scallops to cool off a little while munching on a few fries. The scallops were probably cooked a tad too long, but it was nice and crispy all in all......mmm!! So hot, nicely cooked inside to tender and crispy good. I could not finish all my fries after those yummy scallops, but it filled me up for the rest of the afternoon. I can't wait to go back!
author: Maile N.

description:
Solid oysters. 

Plump, chilled, shucked, and ready to be devoured. 

Three oyster options. $2 a piece on ice. Condiment station on point. Stealth alternative to Hog Island or Waterbar lines. 

This spot does the trick if you're yearning for a quickie oyster slide.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
Though the dungeness crabs in the tank looks fresh and lively. I was very disappointed by their food. Maybe buy the seafood here but wouldn't not eat here...pricey and ruins the lovely flavors of seafood with  lack of knowledge in the fundamentals of cooking....knowing your ingredients. 

Ordered the DUNGENESS CRAB BURRITO and find my food wrapped in foil the size of a sandwich. I thought we got the wrong order, but when we unraveled it, we found two halves of a very skinny burrito. I hoped it would be good but they got it all wrong by treating it like a Mexican Californian buritto. The eggs and cheese overpowered the DUNGENESS CRAB. The avocado would have been great if it weren't for the other items.  I didn't spend $15 for a half ass burrito. The Cole slaw next to it...they can keep that. I want a buritto with substance.
author: Helen L.

description: Took a stop in here on whim. Had to try the smoked salmon breakfast burrito. The flavors were fantastic! The smoked salmon was done right, great texture. Not a filling burrito or big by that matter. But flavorful.
author: Dan L.

description: It's hard to miss the San Fransisco Fish Company when you're strolling through the Ferry Building. They usually have an employee at the front of the house with buckets of ice topped with fresh clams and oysters. These $2 bites are the perfect addition to any food lovers journey through the Ferry Building and are even available at early morning hours as a breakfast protein! Top your bite-sized snack with lemon juice, cocktail sauce or the atomic horseradish--be be warned, it's HOT!
author: Rose L.

description:
I ordered oysters to-go pre-shucked. They were $1.50 each, and were delicious and so much bigger than what I've ever gotten at either Waterbar or Hog Island!

I will definitely come back!
author: Mandi W.

description:
Very good fish and chips and amazing shrimp salad.  The staff was super friendly and even though it was busy, the wait for food was short.  We ended up eating here 3 times during our 10 day trip.   We ordered our fish and chips and went out back to eat on a bench by the water.  Each savory crispy bite of fish dipped in tarter sauce melted in my mouth.  The shrimp salad was awesome!   

They have fresh oyster specials later in the evening and some frozen seafood entrees to bring home.  My husband said the oysters were tasty.
author: Lisa E.

description: I only tried the clam from Long Island, NY and oyster from WA. Soooo fresh! If I wasn't sick. I would eat a dozen of these!! Highly recommend if you come to the Ferry Building and you love oysters!!
author: Linh G.

description: SF fish company is located inside the Ferry Building Marketplace. I was drawn to the shop because of their $2 oysters. I was surprised to find a couple of east coast oysters along with an option harvested from California. I had the option from California and enjoyed it. Additionally, I had some of their tuna poke. I enjoyed it too. All in all, it was no flairs, quality seafood at a fair price.
author: Joseph T.

description: walking in the ferry building during Saturdays Farmer's market, I stumbled upon this place for quick oysters.  oysters were good, selection is minimal.  not sure if they cycle thru the different oysters on a weekly basis or not, but def worth a try at $2ea.
author: Roger K.

description: Over-priced, not really a good place for lunch, because I felt cheated on my crab cake sandwich that had almost no crab.
author: Sea N.

description: Super fresh oysters...grab some everytime we are in town.  Ice cold beer as well!! Great variety of fresh fish..chowders etc as well
author: Steven K.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for awhile.  Today, Friday, was the big day.

I guess my first clue should have been how few people were there just before lunch on a Friday while many other restaurants were more crowded.

I tried their Coconut Shrimp Friday Special for $11.95.  Most places buy these already breaded and frozen, and just fry them up.  To me, these looked and tasted pre-made as well.

Normally, pre-made frozen coconut shrimp are pretty good, as the quality is maintained by the freezing process.

Unfortunately, 2 of my shrimp had a slight iodine smell indicating that they had been thawed too long.  On top of that, all my shrimp were overfried, and basically dried out.  Hence the 2 star review.

In the future, the restaurant should monitor how long the shrimp stored, and fry them less time.

On the fresh fish side, I was shocked to see that they carry Escolar which is banned in Japan.  While it as a nice flavor, many people's systems can't tolerate it due to the wax ester.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escolar
http://blog.medellitin.com/2008/12/escolar-world-most-dangerous-fish.html
author: Roy C.

description: In need of a quick lunch option that went on the side of healthier in the Ferry Building, I came across San Francisco Fish Company.  I was desperate for poke, and was delighted to see they offered it on the menu.  The poke bowl I had was mediocre; the fish was decent, but the rice it was served over was rock hard.  I really didn't have high expectations going into it.  The part that seemed to be overly annoying was that you could order the poke bowl with poke from behind the counter, or the poke bowl that's pre-made.  A word to the wise: the guys behind the counter told me that the pre-made poke bowl is made with fish that's old or scraps.  Seeing how the made-to-order bowl isn't that great either, it certainly makes me wonder what the pre-made bowl is like.
author: Lisa I.

description:
My best friend took me here because she absolutely swore by the food and said it was the best PO' boys she ever had. Sure, why not?! 

For her birthday, we went here because I know she enjoyed it. I liked the food for the most part. We ordered the crab cake sandwich, but the patty was pretty dry to me. I ordered the Oyster Po Boy and it was mostly bread. I could hardly taste the oysters so that was extremely disappointing considering the price point. My favorite thing about the meal was the fries. It was fried to golden perfection! It was delicious.

Don't think I'll be back anytime soon. If I'm in the area, I may give it another shot, but I won't go out of my way to have their food. It's San Francisco! I'm sure there are many other amazing locations that serve the same thing. Gotta step it up!
author: Crystal D.

description:
San Francisco Fish Company is a small place inside the famous Ferry Building where everything is (farmers markets, food places, butchers, etc).

Service is super quick - you're in and out. Order, grab a seat, and in like 5 mins your food will be ready!

I tried the fish and chips and it was soooo good!!! Fish was so (obviously) fresh and it was fried to golden perfection. Squirt some lemon and dunk them in the tartar sauce! The fish wasn't like most places where it would come apart after dipping - the flakiness of the fish held its own really well. The fries were crispy and thin (reminded me of Mickey dees mm) :P
author: Sheena P.

description:
I am only rating the oyster/ clam stand on the outside... have not been inside to their establishment.

They had 2 dollar oysters on Saturday and my friends and I bought 8, 2 each. They got the creamier oysters and I got the less creamier... From our experience the non-creamy oysters are the best.

If you're looking for quick oyster snack, check this place out! Great pit stop if you are shopping at the ferry building!
author: -Johnson- N.

description: Had their oysters at the farmer's market. They were very fresh and only $2 a piece. The lady working the table seemed very unhappy to be there. We also got an order of hot and fresh fish and chips that was very yummy.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
Do you want to avoid the 30 minute line at Hog Island and their $3-$4 oysters? Here's your alternative! San Francisco Fish Company has freshly chucked $2 raw oysters and cherrystone clams!!!! I haven't tried anything else but the oysters are good enough to make me come back. 

Usually they have the Royal Miyagi and the Fanny Bay but they also have Evening Cove and Blue Point sometimes. 

Once you spot the oyster stand as you're walking through the Ferry Buliding, ask the friendly server what each oyster tastes like and choose the appropriate ones to your liking. Or go with my option - don't ask and find out for yourself. After you order, you can put on tobasco, cocktail sauce, or lemon juice which are all lined neatly in front. Then you're on your way to the next food stop. There are also a few tables where you can savor the taste of the sea so you don't have to maneuver the shells and paper plate around the bustling crowds and risk spilling the oyster and lemon juice on someone. 

An important stop for every Ferry Building visit! 

Warning: the cherrystone clams taste wayyyy stronger than the oysters but it's worth it to try the clams at least once
author: Ingrid C.

description: Got food poisoning. It was the blue point oyster. My wife and I even said at time it tasted off and we're thinking about saying something. All the other raw items like the long island clam and like a fanny oyster or something was awesome, so hence not the catastrophic rating. Also, the blue point was the only raw item my wife had, so we can pinpoint our problems to it. Atomic horseradish was good.
author: Morgan C.

description: Their clam chowder bread bowl is so much better than Boudin. Must be the quality of the soup and bread from Acme Bread Company. Fish and Chips are solid - not too greasy. Great lunch!
author: Scott A.

description: My office is close to the Ferry Building and if you've ever been to the Ferry Building, you know there are plenty of places to eat and it can be hard to choose. But San Francisco Fish Company is a great place because the food is fresh, delicious and fast - perfect when you need a quick but satisfying lunch to fuel the rest of your day. I like their fish and chips (very solid, not oily or greasy) and their poke is another favorite. They can also be your fishmonger, so you can take back today's catch and cook it up yourself at home. I recommend them without reservation - hardworking guys behind the counter who care about what they do and provide excellent seafood.
author: Grayson E.

description:
$2 raw oysters that are served upfront and raw clams too!  That is what captivated my attention at this seafood spot.  

They have other deli-type, raw seafood items for sale inside and a menu for cooked seafood selections as well.  Their menu had limited choices and it didn't entice me to order something up from it.

It was my first time trying a raw clam and it was good, but I still prefer raw oysters!  They rotate their raw oysters and clams on a daily basis - depending on the catch!  I liked the raw oyster from Canada vs. the one from Washington.  By the looks and taste of it, the Canada raw oyster was fresher.  

Stop by to try their raw oysters and clams!  It's worth it - especially for $2 a pop!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Having worked Downtown for a while, I used to spend a lot of lunch breaks at the Ferry Building.  If you've been there, you've seen the $2 oysters as you walked by.  Perhaps you've had one.  Have you been in?

So, yes, they're a market.  I can't speak to that.  I can speak to lunch.  They have a nice little menu here, ranging from sandwiches to breakfast burritos to some tasty entrees.  All is ordered at a counter, and it's essentially to go.  They've got some tables.  You can also pick up a beer, and they have a few nice bottle of good craft beers.

I really like the Crab Quesadilla.  It's tasty, and reasonably filling - perfect for lunch.  Served with a side of guacamole.  Yum.  They've good some nice Po' Boys.  I really enjoy the place.  Prices are on the high(er) side, but it's the Ferry Building.  Service is not super-quick, but fine if you're not in a rush.  I'm intrigued to try the Crab Breakfast Burrito.  Just, so many good options, getting down on a Farmer's Market Saturday.
author: Adam S.

description:
Salmon Roll Salad. It's my jam.

Speedwalk down to San Francisco Fish Company and pick up one of their freshly made Salmon Roll Salads. Each salad is comprised of moist salmon wrapped around cooked leeks and then coated in zingy black pepper - on top of a bed of greens with a dill dressing to accompany it.

The salad isn't necessarily mind-blowing - but it's healthy, it's satisfying, and I really enjoy the staff that work here. They're quick to explain any and all ingredients in any of their dishes and if you want any suggestions on what items to order - I highly recommend asking them. 

If you're looking for seafood in the area (outside of Hog Island Oyster Company) check out San Francisco Fish Company.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Nothing I love more than seafood, especially Pacific seafood. For my first trip in the west coast since 1994 (when I was 3) I put seafood, seafood, and seafood as my top 3 priorities in my food adventures. After looking around the ferry building, I came across this place which looked very busy. The menu also seemed very interesting so we decided to eat here.

We ordered the seared tuna burger, crab cake sandwich, steamed shellfish, both clam chowders, and raw oysters (as it was a Tuesday). It might have taken a hit on our wallet a bit, but overall it was definitely worth it. The shellfish (clams, mussels, shrimp, etc) were all fresh and delicious, and the sauce was also unique. I liked both clam chowders, although my dad preferred the New England one. My dad loved the crab cake sandwich, and all of us enjoyed the raw oysters, although the sizes varied quite a bit...probably the only minor disappointment was the seared tuna burger, where it seemed somewhat tasteless.

I'll definitely come back next time I'm in SF! I wish we had seafood this fresh over here.
author: Calvin S.

description:
Did you know? Oysters are hermaphroditic and it is impossible to truly tell their sex at any given time. They appear to be born male, but contain both male and female sex organs, altering sexes periodically over a lifespan. At maturity, most oysters appear to be female. ... is what google says. 
so come on down and get your own hermaphroditic oyster for $2 each!!!
MMmmMM!!!
btw, ..these oysters were the biggest i have ever eating. Milky!!
author: Sherry T.

description:
Going into the Ferry Building was really spectacular because of it's atmosphere. There are so many shops and restaurants inside, so there was a lot to see and plenty of people there to eat and shop. 

My friend and I decided to try out San Francisco Fish Company and overall enjoyed our meal. We took our food to go and sat outside near the deck to eat our food with a good view. I bought the fish and chips, which was a little overpriced I think. I should have tried their po'boy sandwiches instead; it might have made a difference in my experience with them.
author: Sheena V.

description: Really enjoyed their fish and chips, albeit a bit pricey.  It was nicely light batter and the fish was fresh and almost buttery.  Lots of fries included, although we didn't eat much of it.  DW liked the $2/oyster choices.  New England clam chowder was ok, kind of salty for me.  Will definitely come back for the fish and chips!
author: Allen H.

description:
In response to my comment that the $15 breakfast burrito was very small and underseasoned (fact), someone wrote back that, "YOU, THE CUSTOMER MUST BE A FAT COW WHO NEEDS TO LEARN ABOUT PORTION CONTROL."

Wow, thanks! I'm as fit as the average SF'an, but that's pretty special to hear from a professional food vendor. If you happen to post anything the owner doesn't like, don't be surprised if s/he PM's you to call you a fat cow. Not as surprising after reading other people's observations on the unfriendliness of the cashier and other staff.

Also, please know that they sell escolar, banned in some countries because the toxin causes diarrhea.
author: Dennis W.

description:
Any place that has clams on the half shell wins my heart. Especially if I can just eat one as I'm walking by. 

I was trying to finish the last bit of a cheese sandwich from earlier when I saw the clam and oyster table at the front of the SF Fish Co. Sadly, I was really full by this point - I would have ordered a ton of the medium sized clams for $2 each. I only could handle three - and they were delicious!

I miss seeing raw clams at more places; it's much more common on the east coast. These were really good - and each $0.25 less than the ones at Walnut Creek Yacht Club. It was my first time in the Ferry Building and now I can't wait to go back with my appetite and get more clams!!
author: Amy S.

description:
(+) Soft Shell Crab Poboy! I did my research beforehand and since this is such a popular item, I had to try it out. Loved it. I thought it would be pretty heavy for lunch since it's fried but it's actually really light. I love soft shell crab so this was pretty much spot on. The only negative thing I would have to say is that THE SANDWICH IS TINY. From all of the pictures online, I thought it would be pretty decent size since it's pretty expensive ($10.95). Didn't expected it to be that small.... sigh. It is the Ferry Building after all...

(+) Crab Quesadilla.  The crab is so fresh! Yum. This is also pretty pricey but I def thing it's worth trying. I love how the fresh the crab was and you can definitely taste it. it comes in 4 slices so perfect to share with a buddy for lunch. 

(+) Tuna Poke! Yum. I'm so skeptical about eat raw raw fish sometimes but this poke was fresh. For half a pound, we got a good portion in a to-go container that filled us up.

I went around 12:30 (peak lunch hour) and the place as fairly empty (which is great). I love this place but it's definitely on the pricier side. I wish the portions were bigger since I'm paying so much for it but it's a place worth splurging at once in a while if you do your research and know what to get.
author: Tram N.

description: They had a special on oysters, $2 per oyster and they were from different regions, so we got a few.  Yummy.  They had some seating so we snacked on some tasty oysters.
author: Rochelle R.

description: Were being tourists and visiting the Ferry Building. A friend of ours remembered that he loved his fish sandwich here so we stopped by. I ordered the crab cakes and they were very very good. Wife ordered fish and chips and they were outstanding. I love my fish and chips and this might be amongst the best I've had. Not a ton of seating but we were able to find a table shortly after eating. Would definitely return.
author: Izzat A.

description:
Just walking around the embarcadero for lunch and couldn't decide what to eat. Ended up here and ordered the Poki bowl and soft shell sandwich.

The tuna was really fresh and enjoyed the seaweed and sauce they had on it. I wished there were other condiments or sides , kind of expensive for what it is. 3.5 stars.

The sandwich was pretty small and didn't have much flavor until you add the side slaw that came with it. Without it, I'll pass.

Total bill was like $25.
author: Nhung T.

description:
Working right next to the ferry building has been a great way to try  different things. 

1. Crab Cake Sandwich 
- Very tasty
- A lot of Crab
- Fries  on the side (4$) are huge so plan to share 

2. Crab Breakfast Burrito 
- Super yum 
-They cut it in half and then wrap it. I find it makes the tortilla soggy becuase of the grease pouring out of it. Not sure If thats from cooking the eggs. Id say easy on the oil next time. 
- Its basically an omelette of  green onions, and crab. Added avocado wrapped together. Very good
author: Sarra E.

description:
Decent food, great service!

While strolling around Ferry Building, I knew I wanted to get a seafood sandwich of some sort. I looked through a few restaurants and San Francisco Fish Company caught my eye with their oyster and clam table in the front. 

They had sandwiches ranging from Oyster Po Boys to Crab Cake Po Boys, I ended up getting their Fried Soft-Shelled Crab Sandwich on an Acme Roll. ($10.95)

To start off, the roll was delicious! It was soft and just perfect. The sauce that came with the sandwich paired perfectly with the soft-shelled crab. (Wish they gave me a piece of lemon though!) I did let my sandwich sit for a bit while waiting for my friends to get their meal but the crispiness was still there! 

As I was eating the sandwich, the crab legs popped out of no-where. Honestly, I was disgusted by it. The legs were the only part that was soggy, and since it was facing out of the sandwich, they were dangling off the side... I recommend them putting the legs on the inside next time!

Overall, the cashier that helped me was very nice and gave me a lot of recommendations on the sandwiches! It only took around 10 minutes to make, and it was very fresh. Would come again if I want a quick lunch!
author: Winnie I.

description: I used to get 2 oysters every time I pass by the fairy building. It's a really small shop/ restaurant, more like grab-and-go kinda style. The oysters are usually okay. But the quality also varies, sometimes they are not as fresh.
author: Cate L.

description: Current ratings underrate how great this place is. Oysters are $2 at all times and are the freshest, by far largest, and most delicious from what I've had in all of SF. Churn rate is high as well so you keep on getting the freshest available. By far the best deal you can get and if you factor into the fact that these oysters are HUGE, served quickly (no line, no wait), it just remains unclear to me why there aren't rave reviews. Highly recommended.
author: Amy G.

description:
Super fresh oysters! We also ordered the fish and chips, fried scallops and chips and clam chowder in an Acme bread bowl.

Everything was hot, fresh out of the bay and fantastic!
author: Molly M.

description:
Fresh seafood is challenging to find living in Arizona.  As a result, one of the things I love about my frequent visits to San Francisco is going for sushi, fish, oysters and more... 

So on Saturday morning, when looking for the perfect fuel for my hiking and yoga adventure departing from the Ferry Building, the sign for SFFC's breakfast burritos drew me in right away.  A breakfast burrito made with fresh shrimp or crab?  Yes, please!

Luckily, Andrea R, my partner in crime for the day, was agreeable and willing to go for a breakfast burrito also.

We both ordered the Crab Burrito and had no regrets... even with the $14 price tag.  It was so worth it! Made fresh to order, this filling breakfast has it all: egg, cheese, guac, and of course, fresh crab... Served steaming hot within about 8 minutes of ordering, we were in burrito heaven as we sat and ate our burritos, pretty much in silence, so we could relish every bite.  Add a little hot sauce if you're so inclined and thank me later for the rec.  

To note: the burritos are large portions, but not crazy huge; sharing is definitely an option if you're not super hungry.  

I will definitely be back to SFFC... hope to go for some oysters next visit!
author: Gabi M.

description: Soft shell crab po boy was amazing! crispy and flavorful! Their new england clam chowder was yummy too. Not so creamy. $2 oysters are quite economical and there is no line like hog island oysters place.
author: Norases V.

description:
I've always walked by San Francisco Fish Company while inside the Ferry Building, but never really noticed them except for the huge shucked oysters they have out.  Last week my cousin and I met for lunch at the Ferry Building and he suggested this place.  So glad he did, because so many of their menu items sounded so good: scallop and chips, crab cake sandwich, prawn quesadilla, etc.  I ended up getting the scallops and chips, because it was so unusual.  Now, I do love scallops, when they're cooked right, but this is why I don't order them out so much, because half the time they end up coming out rubbery.    

We met up at 11:30, and the Ferry Building was already bustling, most likely due to the Farmer's Market.  There was only one seat available after we placed our order, however, luckily, when we got our food about 5 minutes later, a group of 4 was leaving.  I got 7 decent size breaded scallops with a heaping amount of fries served with the tartar sauce and cocktail sauce ketchup, and both were golden brown (love it).  The scallops were very hot as I bit into them some oil oozed out.  They were very fresh and cooked just right; I loved the breading as well.  I thought the scallops were going to be bigger, but glad they gave me 7 as I was expecting less.  Fries had some crunch to them, though more potatoey.   His soft shell crab sandwich looked great as well.  I totally didn't mind sharing my fries, but felt that for the $11, his sandwich should have included a side of fries, or perhaps a small portion of coleslaw or something.  

I didn't have a reason to eat seafood at the Ferry Building because I don't do oysters (Hog Island Oyster Co.) and am slowly getting into fishes, but now that I know about San Francisco Fish Company's menu, I will definitely be back to try out that crab cake sandwich..or perhaps more scallops and chips!  If they offer those breaded scallops a la carte that would be amazing!  Come visit their storefront to get some fresh delicious seafood.
author: Cat C.

description:
Came to visit SF and was in the area for lunch. Of course I had to stop by one of my favorite spots in the Ferry Building. As usual, $2 fresh shucked clams and oysters. I spent about $20 on them. Clams were meaty, juicy and sweet and oysters were fresh and creamy. Of course, I added a a splash of tabasco, lime juice and horseradish. Perfect little snack and definitely worth the price. Won't get any fresher than this!

5 Stars for their raw clams/oyster booth. Never had any of their hot foods.
author: Juan F.

description:
I'm glad Yelp gives us an opportunity to update reviews.  A year ago I reported on the horrible biology project that is their live tank for crab, and the quality of their product..  I'm still hesitant to shop there although I do stop by a few times a week to visit the other merchants in the ferry building.

For at least 6 months, they have kept the live tanks consistently clean.  And that's a good sign.  The fresh fin fish which was never a problem still looks good.  I want to like them because they are my neighborhood fishmonger.  They have improved a lot, and should be recognized for that.
author: John B.

description: Raw oysters and clams daily! Kendrick thanks for taking of us and walking us through the differences in oysters!
author: Chris Z.

description:
Delicious fresh seafood is what comes to mind when I think of the San Francisco Fish Company. On Tuesdays they have a small raw oyster bar available in the front of the store. I enjoyed the couple of oysters I ate. They were fresh, mild and tender. 

The fresh fish counter is well stocked with a variety of seafood.

There is a limited menu of cooked seafood options but what they do they do well. A few of the items includes blue crab, shrimp,oyster or dungeness crab cake po boy sandwiches. Today there was an option of clam chowder, but I didn't try it. The weather was too warm to eat soup. There are other options but I had the blue crab po boy. It was soooo good. I appreciate the fact that when I asked the guy that was ringing my order up what was his recommendation for something good, he was honest and explained why he recommended the blue crab sandwich. He was right. I loved it. The other person in my party had the shrimp po boy and I tasted that too. That was tasty as well.

I must admit eating in San Francisco can be quite pricey. This place falls into that category. For what my party ordered it was kind of expensive.

There is not a lot of room to eat here but if you can't get a seat you can always go outside and eat as you look out at the beautiful bay.
author: Chardonnai S.

description:
I wanted to go to Market Bar - beautiful day, off hours, small plates but the beezie (lol) I was with said it was too expensive. I have never been to Market Bar and I have been wanting to try it forever. I guess I am too nice. I should have reminded her I was buying and she should stop tripping.

I had the soft shell crab po boy ($10.95) and she had the quart of clam chowder ($16). She said she wanted to save some for later. The place was out of bread so she only received oyster crackers. The pic of the Bay Bridge was the best part of the meal. The soft shell crab was more like a 1/2 a crab and it did not have much flavor. The bread was nothing like New Orleans or SF for that matter. The clam chowder was so-so also. The only saving grace for the place was the fresh oysters @ $2 each and the people were pretty nice.

I don't know why I hang around my wing gal who lives up here. She rarely goes to SF and when she does she is so indecisive. I guess it is because we have been frends forever. Any Yelpers want to meet me in SF the next time I am in the area? - LOL
author: Joe P.

description: The food was only okay; crab cake sandwich was more like a veggie burger with a little crab; fries portion was large and tasty, but too much for me as a side. We had asked about the fries and gotten told is was "regular" size - couldn't figure it out so ordered too much. They close 6:30 and you need to be out the door by 7.  The place was clean and there are a few places to sit, but it isn't a true restaurant dine-in experience.
author: wen m.

description: I was excited to come here because the Marketplace is pretty popular, and I had never been there. How can you go wrong with a seafood place in S.F? Well, you can. I made the mistake of ordering a crab cake sandwich. The crab cake hardly had any flavor, and did not taste like it had crab in it. Highly disappointed. I let my husband have a bite, and he said it wasn't good. My husband used to eat canned spinach, so for him to say it's not good, believe it. The 3 stars is because the lobster roll HE ordered was delish! I wish I ordered that instead. Kids had fish n chips, that was pretty good. That would've been better than the sandwich I ordered. Oh well, I will know for next time.
author: Mamma C.

description:
A seafood shop in the Ferry Building Marketplace, the San Francisco Fish Company lured me in on an early morning when I was searching for breakfast and my last meal in SF, primarily by having the magic words on their chalkboard list of specials: fish tacos.  Most of the store is behind a counter displaying their extensive raw seafood selection for purchase, and while I was there, they moved a wooden counter out front that functioned as a portable raw bar to attract passerby's.  Unlike many other shops in the Ferry Building, they also have an L-shaped counter for dining in, with about 10 stools available.

The fish tacos, 3 to an order for $11, had sizable chunks of lightly fried, flaky, fresh fish and topped with shredded lettuce, red cabbage, onion, and a light salsa verde.  The tortillas were unforgivably cold and sprung leaks, and the salsa was not anywhere near flavorful enough, although hot sauce helped some.  The only plus was the fish quality but these were not good fish tacos, very disappointing.  They need to pick a better way to showcase their seafood.
author: Valery C.

description: I tried the raw oysters and clam at the front of the stall and I'm in love. They were $2.00 each and was worth every penny.  They had all the condiments sitting up front.  Next time I want to actually eat at this place and have the raw oysters for dessert.
author: Rena H.

description:
All it took was a sign.
Granted, it was a stand up one that was near the walkway, but those two magic words, "Lobster chowder" widened my eyes in a San Francisco second. (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=9_72XG1rh8Ofvdd9hFIqug&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q)
Before you knew it, I was examining the rest of the menu and the pint was in my shopping bag with some oyster crackers.
Besides this, I also picked up a pint of their Manhattan clam chowder (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=FIR6yA1eLJRYKNnpY-lPnQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q). I reheated this later in the week for lunch and was a perfect accompaniment to Downtown Bakery's spinach bacon ricotta turnover (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) for lunch.
If you are a lobster fan, soup fan, or just plain love seafood, you'll probably find sort of ocean candy here.  
The soups definitely did not disappoint here.
author: Mike C.

description:
The SF Fish Company is located within the Ferry Building Marketplace. My boyfriend and I were gawking at the oysters that were displayed within the area. We just had to have them!

[devour]
OYSTERS ($2 each; **4 STARS**) were pretty good! The SF Fish Company had shucked oysters on display outside of their venue. As my boyfriend and I were walking by, we oohed and aahed and decided to each have an oyster as part of our lunch. Condiments were available on the side. I had heard there was another oyster place in the Ferry Building, and unfortunately I didn't find it until we were about to leave (making mental note to go there first next time I'm in the area). (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-fish-company-san-francisco?userid=lj3rJy1dUuHMDnqU_OCfsA#TNtf7O0d_0A-enxuSx9Q4w)

"Award Winning" GUMBO (**2 STARS**) was NOT award winning in my book. Gumbo is supposed to have a thick consistency and I didn't get that. Gumbo is supposed to have that "thick" stew-like broth, instead it was more soup-like. On the bright side, the gumbo had lots of items and the spices were reminiscent of my trip to NOLA and were spot on. Hopefully the consistency can be improved. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/san-francisco-fish-company-san-francisco?userid=lj3rJy1dUuHMDnqU_OCfsA#9WoM3ZWz85DOkEWJrzIyHg)

Although we had a few hits and misses, we didn't get to try the other items on their menu. I wouldn't mind checking this place out again for their other seafood dishes or even purchasing some of the seafood they have on display (like a butcher shop). 

Overall, not too shabby!

Yelp 2013 100+ Reviews Challenge (going for 200!) - Review #116
author: Kristen M.

description:
I stopped by because I was tempted by the display of shucked oysters and clams. I was walking around the ferry building with a friend for lunch and chanced upon this place.

It's only $2 for a raw oyster or clam, no tax! They have all the toppings you want right there in front, including lemon, atomic horseradish (it's got a kick!), tabasco, and cocktail sauce. Today they had Blue Point oysters from New England, so I got one. It was really nice and firm and tasty.

My friend got a seared swordfish sandwich to go, and that wasn't too unreasonable, about $11.50 for the sandwich. The fish here isn't too outrageously expensive either. They have fresh sea urchin!
author: Michael W.

description: I can't stop coming to this place even if I don't have any reason to be downtown. It's great for lunch -- tuna burger excellent, tuna poke highly recommended. I'm always impressed by how knowledgeable and friendly the staff is-- they know a remarkable amount about what they sell and never steer me wrong, whether for menu items or if I'm buying seafood to cook at home. I usually go on Tuesdays and Saturdays. Saturdays are crazy but they still somehow function. Highly recommended and worth the trip across town or across the Bay.
author: Elea C.

description: Just enjoyed a delicious oyster po boy.  I am pregnant so limited on oyster options. But this is a great way to taste oysters.  My hubby enjoyed the raw oysters and liked them.  Po boy was one of the best I have ever had... Almost wish I didn't share with the hubs... Wish I had my own.  The side of coleslaw was also yummy.
author: Lauren W.

description:
I don't know anything about seafood but when I walked by, I wanted a raw oyster because I wanted to feel what I felt when I was in New York; I tried my very 1st raw oyster in Greenwich Village at The Mermaid Oyster Bar 2 years ago.  I felt happy at the time because I was able to go on vacation (albeit a short one) w/o the kids and I got to do what I want to do - walk all day, walk all afternoon, walk all evening, eat, eat, and eat.  I loved it.  

Unfortunately, I did not have cash though.  An oyster is $2 and they had 3 different kinds.  I asked the guy for the least ocean-y one so he gave me the Long Island one. After my daughter paid for me (I did pay her back), I let her have the first bite.  She put a little cocktail sauce but didn't really like it.  After that, I put some lemon and Tabasco on my oyster and took it like a shot.  It was still very salty but this is coming from someone that doesn't eat seafood.  

For the experience alone - 4 stars.
author: Tram N.

description:
Oysters and chips were delicious, piping hot and fresh.  We got 4 oysters lightly battered and deep fried to perfection. 

Prawns and chips were delicious but we preferred the oysters.  

They were also offering $2 shucked clams and oysters. The couple in front of us each ate about a dozen and said they were extremely fresh and meaty.  

Seating is limited but you can always eat outside by the water as well.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Delicious Gazpacho. I wish I had a big bowl and stuck with that. We shared a Crab Cake Sandwich and Smoked Herring Burrito. 
The crab cake was predominately mushy filling on a nice roll. Since it's crab season, I was expecting big chunks of fresh crab but it was sadly lacking. I think they run the heavy  filler and some crab (not the best pieces) through a processor and then fry it. 
Skipped the Cole slaw it came with.
I thought the burrito had some big taste but it sure sat heavy in my stomach.
It was very tiny and as rich as it was, I wouldn't have wanted more.
The men behind the counter were very nice. Great spot to people watch.
author: Diane W.

description:
The crab cake sandwich, whilst topped with a perfect aioli, was entirely wrong and tasted more like falafel than crab. As a proud Marylander I should have known better!

But the fish n' chips? Oh my that was good.

The only criticism of the fish n' chips is that it comes out at close to a million degrees and can't reasonably be touched for a solid ten minutes. Ten difficult minutes. But when you finally can dive in it's a treat. The fish is moist and full of flavor, and the breading is crisp and just the right amount of salty. The chips may be even better; they're practically divine when dipped in tartar sauce.

The service is also crazy fast. We ordered and had our food in minutes. It's not the cheapest place around ($12-14 for most sandwiches and entrees) but you're in the Ferry Building and it's not likely to get cheaper any time soon!

They also have a dungeness crab breakfast burrito. You better believe I'll be back for that sucker some day, Marylander blood or not.
author: Nick S.

description: This used to be a great spot for casual dining. The crab burrito used to have so much meat inside but now, not only did it get smaller but it's All eggs.  It should be called an Egg burrito.  Prices have gone up but the quality has gone Way down!  I won't be going back.
author: Van N.

description:
I was walking around the Ferry Building on a Sunday morning when I saw their sign for breakfast burritos. The burritos come with 3 eggs, green onions, cheese, and guacamole with your choice of protein. I chose the smoked salmon. I was pretty much sold when I saw the word burrito & was excited to try this place when they listed out the fillings. What could go wrong?!

I'll tell you! It was tiny! TINY! The burrito came out to $11 dollars and was served piping hot wrapped in foil. I couldn't believe it costed so much for such a tiny serving. 

All of the ingredients were fresh and blended well together. Also the salmon had a strong smokey flavor if that is your thing. It was a really fresh seafood burrito but I wish you got a bigger bang for your buck.
author: Donna N.

description: fresh oysters :-) love the Royal Miyagi (Canada) taste is more creamy. Blue Point (New Jersey) is chewy and smaller.
author: Karen C.

description: So every time I come to The City I have to get clam chowder and some kind of seafood plate whether it's fish and chips or steak and lobster which is my all time fave. I can say the food here was alright. A little pricey compared to food you can get just down the street on pier 39, but not too bad in taste. Service was horrible, not friendly at all and when I asked the expo for more crackers for my clam chowder he said, " I gave you two you want more?!" I answered back and said well yes please if that's ok? He grabbed two more packets when I only asked for one and he damn near slammed it into my hand. I won't come back to this place. There's no good seating, too expensive, no good ventilation, horrible service. You are better off walking another 1/2 a mile or so to pier 39!
author: Michael C.

description: $2 oyster bar... it's hard to walk by and not stop to get a quick bite since it's in your face. You get 3 choices. The quality is okay and I liked the toppings bar.
author: Joleen Q.

description:
I love The Ferry Building and I love every cafe, shop, stall, eatery inside it. So yes, of course, I really like the San Francisco Fish Company. The staff are so nice, the food is cheap, delicious and fresh. 

I had a crab sanga here and loved it. I wouldn't have eaten more and I had my eye on the tacos and Burrito but I had to give up on them in order to complete my mission, which was to taste a bit of everything at other places. 

If you're ever in San Fran, don't make the same mistake I made and leave this place last on your list. Bring it all the way to the top because you'll want to come back a few more times after. 

This place is truly great - they sell fresh seafood and cooked ones as well. I love it and I shall return on my next visit!
author: Kevin S.

description:
I am in a quandary. A quandary I face from time to time when I come across a dish so good I don't want the potential of it becoming popular. Mind you these are simply my taste buds and palette talking so for anyone else it may be simply average.  I can comfortably say in my heart of hearts San Francisco Fish Company makes the best Fish in a Fish & Chips I've ever had in the Bay Area. On it's own the fish is perfectly made with just the right amount of seasoning in the breading to pair with the perfectly flaky cod. When showered with the proper amount of vinegar it takes on an entirely different personality. An amazing one at that. Sadly the Chips don't hang with the fish at all.  It would be cool if they would ramp up the latter end of the dish to really make the Fish and Chips experience that much better. 

There are other positive to the Fish Co. like the rotating fresh oysters and clams served as you walk by.  I've shopped here before as well and have always been helped by a consistently friendly and informative staff.  As great as it is they do have some misses like Shrimp Creole and like I mentioned the fries. The breakfast burritos are hit and miss too.  The sandwiches in my experience have all been fantastic along with the fresh seafood to enjoy at home.
author: Joco F.

description:
My husband and I just had our breakfast here a few minutes ago.
We ordered Dungeness Crab burrito, whiskey sage sausage burrito, New England chowder, and Fresh oysters. 
New England chowder tasted different, but in a good way. It's nice and rich! Good for starting your day.
My husband got his whiskey sage sausage burrito and was a bit hesitant at first because he saw the amount of avocado that was in it. (He didn't know it has mashed avocado since there wasn't really a description of every item in the menu). He doesn't really like avocado, at all. But I was surprised when I saw him finish all of it when I'm just half way with mine (I am not a slow eater. But to be fair, I'm the only one who ate the clam chowder). He said that the proportion is just right and the avocado didn't bother his taste buds at all. 
For the Dungeness crab burrito, well... to be honest, I was still hungry for the chowder. If I didn't ate all the chowder, I might say that the proportion of my burrito would've been just right. But then again, I was still eyeing for the fresh oysters (Yes, I really love seafood). I didn't really taste the crab flavor, but it's probably because of the chowder. I loved the avocado. The taste of freshly squeezed lime on it  is just spot on! (I was actually grossed out of the taste of avocado since I was little. But when I moved to California from Philippines, I just had to try to like it. Almost all the asian menu here has avocado. Especially the California rolls which is my favorite back in the Philippines, but instead of avocado, we put mangoes. And since the mangoes here doesn't really taste good, I started learning how to appreciate avocado. And guess what, now I an avocado lover. Haha) I wish there was cilantro in it. Or if there was, I didn't taste it at all.
Overall, crab burrito is okay. It probably contains at least 3 eggs which is cholesterol overload. It would've been better if they had half sizes, they would sell more of their other menu items.
Fresh oysters. Mmmmmm. One of my seafood favorites!
$2 each and it is worth it! The sweetness and freshness of it made me want to order more. (But I didn't because we're just about to go to the Food Festival a few hours later. And my husband said that I shouldn't eat too much since there's going to be more food to try later on)
It's comparable to Hog Island Oysters. And much more affordable.

I would probably go back for more oysters and clam chowder. Burrito is just too heavy for me.
author: Kam V.

description:
O to the M to the G.... So delicious 
Had the smoked salmon burrito.
Amazing flavor and consistency.
Served piping hot.
Totally recommend this place.
author: Travis W.

description: This is a favorite lunch spot at the ferry building. I always get the scallop and chips, and the wife gets a po' boy and is always happy with the results. Seating can be a bit tricky because there aren't a lot, but that's the only con I can think of. I highly recommend.
author: Vic M.

description:
I stopped here for a quick lunch. There was almost no line (1 person ahead of me).

Recommend the shellfish in white wine, butter, and garlic. It was so good. Totally worth the money that I spent. I don't feel like it was that expensive for what I got and generally being in a SF touristy spot.

I would definitely come back the next time I was in town.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Came here with some friends when we couldnt decide what to get in the Ferry Building. It really shouldn't be that hard right? Well I think we all wanted to try something we hadn't had before. Kind of disappointed. It wasn't bad, but we could have had a much better experience eating other foods. 

I ordered the crab cake sandwich and my other companions ordered the crab quesadilla and the fried catfish. My crab cake sandwich was good - but not super amazing. The coleslaw was probably the best part of the dishes. 

I'll have to try the po boys I guess to really get a full experience of the place.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Came here with Blair. She's blonde and Asian - a combo of 2 of my favorite types of people. Anyways, I got the Po Boy Sandwich. Solid. We went outside to eat along the pier. Blair picked a spot to sit down where there wasn't that much bird poo. We stared out towards the water and her blonde hair was blowing in the wind. The only thing that made it kinda sucky were the birds. They got so close to us! Like literally they were sitting next to me. I told her she picked a really bad spot and she chuckled and said my name outloud with a cheerful and playful tone. I started to sweat, so we took a walk where it was more breezy. 

I mentioned we were making lettuce wraps at Calvin's hookah lounge, and Blair invited herself over. I said it was ok even though I don't even pay rent there. I told the hookah lounge management of her invitation and they ok'ed it. The lettuce wraps turned out to be a complete success! Mostly because Mike's plants aren't on the kitchen table anyways so we can eat like normal human beings and not stand and eat. 

It's Calvin's birthday today btw. He's turning 26. He's a curvy fellow with a unique sense of humor. He did most of the chopping for the lettuce wraps. Click 'funny' 'helpful' and 'cool' and I will send you the recipe for the wraps!
author: Aron M.

description:
Ahi poke is fresh and just like Hawaii (as I miss it so).
Oysters fresh, sweet, and large.
When I go to Ferry Plaza, this will be my new regular stop time and again!
author: David H.

description:
Oh the food in this place is so good in this very casual spot! 

This place has counter service with very little seating.  So if you can carry your food outside and eat, that might be your only option.

I had the butter/garlic/wine steamed mussels.  The most fresh and tender mussels that I have had in a looooong time!  The fresh bread that came along with it was perfect for sopping up the delicious broth that it came in.
