We also tried the fish and chips and it too was a winner!!! Crispy light beer batter surrounded a flaky/firm fresh white fish (cod?).  What's important to me when having fish/chips was that the oil is fresh and non existent, you get that when you flash fry and that's what this meal tasted like.  

I can't wait to visit the ferry bldg again just to visit this place.
author: amy m.

description: Ordered Dungeness Crab Burrito. A very small skinny burrito in which you can only taste eggs. $15 is too much for a tiny burrito which taste like eggs.
author: Rashid T.

description:
Do you love oysters? Do you find yourself at the Ferry Building? If this is you & if it's around 3 in the afternoon, then stop by the San Francisco Fish Company. Always love when they have their fresh shucked oyster cold bar outside their storefront. $2 oysters on the half shell. Their variety changes often. When I was there on Friday, they offered 2 types. Oysters from New Jersey and Washington. Some days they offer up to 3 or 4 varieties. You just have to catch them!

Photo - Storefront (Fresh Oyster Bar): http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fGVkpBzAAZ3sKQ7Zqow1qg&userid=c97OX3kwpvfP00nat54qiw

Eat it... Love it?... YELP IT!!!
author: Joel R.

description:
The fried fish was quite good, nicely fried.
Fries were crispy and tasty.
author: Corey L.

description:
I went here last weekend to try the soft shell crab po'boy and I was really impressed. Everything from the flavor of the crab & bread, the texture & even the portion was better than I expected. Reading other reviews about the portion led me to expect a baby-sized sandwich, but it came out a well enough size with a generous amount of crab. Currently priced at $12.95 for just the sandwich, I wasn't too surprised just because you're in a tourist area - everything's gonna be a little pricey. Ordered a side of fries with it, an extra $5, came out overly salted. I would recommend to order it with no salt & salt it yourself. 

This company also sells fresh seafood to take home & other lunch items like fish & chips, different versions of po'boys & oysters that they prepare for you to eat with all the condiments. It all looked so yummy. 

I specifically went here just for the crab po'boy sandwich & did not leave disappointed. Do yourself a favor if you're visiting the Ferry Building, try their Soft Shell Crab Po'boy. Also, grab a table as soon as you can, people are scavenger's for seating!
author: Krystle L.

description: Coconut shrimps were overcooked and did not taste fresh. Agua Fresca was delicious, fish and chips were fine, smoked salmon burrito was quite flavorless. Would not recommend eating here, but they sell seemingly fresh fish!
author: Olivier L.

description:
Just not good tasting. We were hungry and so was our son, so after seeing the longer lines at other places, we just decided to get sandwich sand soup.
We ordered the following: halibut sandwich, cod sandwich, Manhattan chowder soup, and fries.. Everything was pretty disgusting to say the least. Fish was chewy and didn't taste all that fresh, bread looked and tasted cheap (like the ones you get from a crappy grocery store 4 rolls for $1 kind of bread) Manhattan chowder was watery, very tomato paste taste and no fish to speak of.. (One of the worst soups I have had) and fries were a greasy mess. 

All day long I had major indigestion after consuming this place. Never again..
author: Eunhee K.

description:
First experience was having their oysters.  I thought it was a great idea for them to have oysters on half shell ready to be purchased and slurped!   

Our recent experience was trying their poke - it's one of the already made salads, not on the lunch menu.  It was good, just lacking a bit of flavor.
author: Gloria H.

description: Walked by here during my lunch break and saw their oyster stand for $2 oysters. I LOVE oysters so I had to buy a few to try. I really liked the Cherrystone oysters they had yesterday because it had a nice sweet taste to it. The other oyster (I forgot the name) but it was super large and delicious too! Definitely will be back for oysters and to try their sandwiches, which I heard from my co-workers were pretty good.
author: Amanda C.

description: Nothing Fancier than $2 oysters on a paper plate!  I didn't even think I liked oysters.  We tried one of each.  They have all the fixings, horseradish, cocktail sauce, hot sauce, lemon juice.  I loved both the oysters in different ways.  Quick little pit stop.  They look like they have a killer Crab Louie salad.  Will definitely be stopping back in here next time we are in town.
author: Christina P.

description:
Have you tried the fish tacos? Were they as big as your head? 
What's that? You have a huge head? Well, they're THAT big. 

Holy tacos. 

My one food goal, when visiting San Francisco, was to eat fresh sourdough bread and to have some fish tacos. Check. Mate. 

While touring the ferry building during the lunch rush, this fish market caught my eye. I asked the stone-faced man behind the register how the tacos were. He paused for a second and replied, "they're so good. I mean...so good." Lack of emotion aside, I trusted him for some reason. I ordered and waited with my delicious Izze. 

When he delivered said lunch tacos...he had a wry grin on his face. It was as if was proud of me for ordering them and he looked like he wanted to stand behind me and watch me eat them (to make sure I approved of them). 

The 3 tacos were the size of a small baby. Everything was light, fresh, flavorful and simple. I didn't have room for 3 tacos but I didn't leave a drop behind. 

The short version - I liked the tacos and I think you might too. :-)
author: Mark F.

description:
While walking around the Ferry Building, I stopped in here to pick up a piece of fish for dinner.
I was really disappointed that almost none of the fish was local, and many varieties weren't even from the U.S. The man who waited on me seemed a little out of it, he wasn't very helpful, and was a bit standoffish. He also removed the skin from the salmon, (i didn't notice until got home) I was SO disappointed.

All that being said, the Loch Duart salmon i purchased was delicious, and a few dollars cheaper than the same salmon from my local market.
We also purchased some oysters that my husband grilled that night, and they were fantastic.

If i was in the Ferry Building for lunch, I'd love to try their seared ahi sandwich.
author: Amanda G.

description: This is a small space in the Ferry Building. When I was there on the weekend, it was really busy. Since there were no chairs and everyone was either waiting in line to order, or waiting for their food, nowhere to sit down. Take your food outside and eat on the benches facing the ferries or the bridge. They had raw oysters on the half shell, but not sure I would risk eating raw oysters nowadays. They also have a fresh fish counter, but you can probably find better and cheaper elsewhere. The real draw are the sandwiches; Po Boys, crab cake, soft-shell crab, seafood burritos, etc. Good variety and a decent choice for a meal if you are in the area or about to take a ferry. Not a destination though. Casual take-out joint, no table service, or any room to eat in.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I have been in search for a place that has above average Fish & Chips and I decided to check this place out.  Along with me I decided to drag along my co-workers/friends.  We ended up ordering 1 order Fish & Chips and 1 order Scallops and Chips.  The Fish & Chips are definitely a hit here.  The scallops were ok, and I would probably go back just to try it one more time to be sure I didn't come on a super busy time and that's why it was mediocre.  I want to give it a second shot.  However, my friend decided since the first two things we ordered were successful they wanted to go back and try other items.  So, we did we ordered Seafood Jambalaya,Seafood Gumbo and I personally had clam chowder.  I would have to say that these items I would not come back for.  They were not anything special.  Just to be fair, they have a good variety of fresh fish to purchase and take home to cook yourself.  

Next time, I will try their oyster and po-boy sammy.

Hope this helps.
author: Kathy C.

description:
Located in the Ferry Building with many lunch options, we just happened to take a chance with this one and I hate to say it but I wish we picked somewhere else. Though seafood is their specialty, they bring nothing new to the table and I was left with an overall bland experience.

I got the Shrimp Po' Boy and my friend got their daily special of the Cod & Chips. The shrimp were lightly battered and fried but the batter lacked flavor and the shrimp were just soggy instead of crispy. At least the bread was soft so I wasn't left with the roof of my mouth all scratched up. They gave a "side" of coleslaw which was literally only 2 bites. The cod & chips were also pretty bland. At about $13 for my meal, it was overpriced and really not worth it at all.
author: Alysha F.

description:
Walked by,  saw oysters staring back at me. Had to eat them. At $2 each,  I tried the different varieties they had. The server knew how to describe the difference in flavors very well. 
Visitors must take this quick 5 minute pause to eat some fresh oysters. Good experience.
author: Jaime L.

description:
I ordered fish tacos and cup of clam chowder, and it was too much food!
Barely finished it!
The clam chowder was real good!
Next time I will just get bigger size clam chowder! 
And that will be just enough!
Instead of eating too much!
author: Vivian G.

description:
As San Francisco tourists, we HAD to check out the Ferry Building and the goodness that was inside.  We walked around, had samples of bread and flavored olive oil, some coffee, and then stopped in front of the San Francisco Fish Company and drooled over the oysters that were on display for sale at the front of the store.

We decided to try two oysters.  The Mister tried his oyster and instantly fell in love.  He said that the oyster was so good that he would've hit me!

Digression:  Have you seen that episode of the Dave Chappelle show when Arsenio Hall tried some cheese and he stopped and said "This is some good ass cheese!  You didn't tell me y'all got some good ass cheese here!" and then proceeded to punch the guy in the face?  Well, that's what we think about when we come across good ass food.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LZVIBwPAhUY

The oyster was clean and fresh and didn't have any hard bits in it.

We walked around to check out the other stores, only to find ourselves at the oyster stand again.  This time we had more oysters!  It would be safe to say that these are some good ass oysters!
author: Tricia G.

description:
tl;dr; Fried oyster Po'boy, enough said.

There are variety of hot items with their fresh seafood ingredients.  I have tried the Cod n' chips, but I didn't cod too much.  Thought the texture of the fish is somewhat too firm.  

My s.o. ordered the Fried oyster Po'boy.  It was delicious.  Lightly-breaded oyster, topped with lettuce in a sandwich.  

The customers next us order this good looking shrimp breakfast burrito. They kept saying its amazing.  So I am excited to go back next around to try that.
author: Steven M.

description:
My head just exploded with joy!
After wandering through the farmer's market we stopped and got freshly shucked oysters ($2 each) a little tabasco, a bit of lemon, a very happy customer.
I shall return.
author: Scott H.

description: Terrific lunch place. Love the burger there! Tried oyster burger, soft shell crab burger and smoked salmon. Love them!
author: QL M.

description:
Details:
Usually lunchtime, during the week, on my own. 

Setting:
Inside the Ferry Building, they are almost always busy during lunchtime, but that doesn't mean slow. They slid have a butcher on site for seafood.

Meals:
I usually get a fish sandwich from their daily special board: tilapia, swordfish or halibut. They are plain and delicious, served on a soft French roll with sauce only, and  come with a side of coleslaw. If I manage to get a bar stool I eat in, otherwise they wrap it up, put it in a paper bag to go.

Staff:
Is friendly and helpful.

Rating:
Five stars. They do a few things really well.
author: Jesse V.

description: I'm not sure that the crab cake sandwich had any crab in it. It was really a party of bread crumbs and seasoning that had been fried.
author: Sandra T.

description: Today's Halibut and chips (fries) was outstanding! The fish was delicate, buttery, flaky, with a light crisp batter. I was the first customer of the day, so it came almost instantly. Plenty of seats now, too. I've had the gumbo and chowder here before. - also excellent, but it gets crowded after noon and insane on weekends. Come early, if you can!
author: Anna L. C.

description: Had the soft shell crab PO'Boy - New Orleabs style. Was one of the best things I've eaten!
author: Margot E.

description: I'd recommend anyone to get their $2 oysters instead of dining in a restaurant at Embarcadero, as its fast and satiates your seafood cravings anytime. The Blue Point or Miyagi oysters are my favorite - salty, briny and oceanic in flavor.
author: Vhalerie L.

description:
OHHHHHHH...
Who lives in a pineapple under the sea?
SpongeBob SquarePants!
Absorbent and yellow and porous is he!
SpongeBob SquarePants!
If nautical nonsense be something you wish!
SpongeBob SquarePants!
Then drop on the deck and flop like a fish!
SpongeBob SquarePaaaaannttss!!!

SpongeBob sure loves his Krabby Patties...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lW_UUDtNQXk
...and we may have more in common than our yellow skin since I may start to develop similar feelings for the tasty $8.50 Soft-Shell Crab Sandwich at the SF Fish Company (see photo). So fresh. Lightly breaded. Not greasy. Soft bun. It's almost as good as the one they serve at Chow on Wednesdays for lunch.

On a nice day, take it to go and sit on one of the benches to eat them. But do be careful because you may have to face a swarm of pigeons and seagulls not unlike the schoolyard scene in "The Birds" when Tippi Hedren was smoking a pack of Winstons (unfiltered of course) little realizing the birds were gathering on the jungle gym. RUN KIDS!!!

FOOD - 4 stars...a damn good sandwich for a sucker of soft-shell crab like myself
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...well, really three stars for the cramped quarters at the Ferry Building location but push it to four on a nice day at the pier
SERVICE - 4 stars...top-notch by a fine, friendly crew of mongers
TOTAL - 4 stars...oh and they sell fresh fish, too...check it out!
author: Ed U.

description:
Burned too many times by the apathy and/or incompetence of my local Whole Foods fish department, I started coming here and I have never regretted that change.  The fish is all fresh and wonderful, and they do a beautiful job de-boning it.  The shellfish is excellent as well.  Coming down here to have a few oysters and then picking out something for dinner is one of the great things about living in the City.

Also, if you're lazy (like me!) hit up their prepared foods.  It feels quaint to rave about tuna salad but my God is their tuna salad good.  The best tuna salad, possibly.  The salmon salad is also excellent.  You really can't go wrong.
author: Kevin S.

description:
SF Fish Co. offers GREAT seafood!  They have different varieties of seafood including soft shell crabs, razor clams, and LIVE SCALLOPS! I couldn't believe they have better varieties than some asian market that I've been to.  I have yet to wait and see if SF Fish Co. will stock some fresh live abalones.  I can't wait for the soft shell crab season to come!

For a quick lunch, I always ordered their oyster po-boy and raw clams and oysters. The oysters were nicely fried and tasted excellent.  Except  maybe only one time I got one that came with tiny oysters.  Their raw clams and oysters are also my favorites.  The crab cake po-boy is equally good.
author: Shirley H.

description: They have a cart you can buy fresh oysters from in the market place. Good fresh oysters on the go!
author: Erika C.

description: Their Prawns and Chips is the best shrimp I've ever had. Unfortunately it's only a special so it's hit or miss if they have it. The Coconut shrimp was over cooked, but the Oysters were so good! Crab cake sandwich is also super good and this is a place I always go when I'm in SF.
author: Tim C.

description: Um, ordered the crab cake sandwich based on another review here and it was awful - first off, no crab taste, all filler and very dense; I didn't even finish it.  I'm not sure it had any crab in it.  I couldn't even figure out what it was made of.   Usually I can rescue something like this with tartar sauce but that didn't work.  The fresh oysters offered at the front looked really good, though.
author: Susan F.

description:
There's something amazing in just strolling by the farmers market picking up whatever is seasonal and then after walking in here for a freshly shucked oyster that you can just drop your two bucks, top it with some horseradish and hot sauce and suck it down like a champ.

You'll be going back for another and another and another. They're fast food that you can respectably enjoy.... Not to mention being amazingly delicious. They have a few to choose from and you can get some clams. While you may turn your head at clams when there's oysters abound, they are really tasty.   

It's also a solid place to get some fresh fish for a meal you plan to cook up and they do have a lot of other prepared dishes that will blow your taste buds out of the water.
author: Javier J.

description:
This place never made me sick til yesterday but before that it was always overpriced and had small portions. Yesterday ate a cod sandwich that had bones in it, disgusting bad lettuce. Honked a couple hours later and am still sick.

Never going here again. Now my weekend is ruined thanks to their slop.
author: Heber S.

description:
This place reminds me of the fish market section of the grocery store. Nothing like a restaurant feel at all. Lol. 

So I'm in Cali and I"m thinking, "Hot damn! I gotta order a fish taco now!" So I am all excited thinking I'm finally going to eat authentic fish tacos. And my order comes out and.....

I'm disappointed. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/ZORLo_6N469WNoM-tpOxHg/l The fish had no flavor to it, and there was too much lettuce and sauce which was dripping everywhere! Sad to say, but I enjoyed the fish tacos from my town on the East Coast a lot better. =(

Next time I'll make sure to try fish tacos elsewhere in San Francisco.
author: Julie A.

description: Been here several times.  Small little area for quick oysters. Loved it until the senior person there didn't want to adjust my  payment despite me ordering before the end of happy hour. No big deal as it was only $2 . Just the condescending way he talked to me. He does good business with the tourists who he jokes around with.  Seems to ignore me and the wife mostly. He won't miss my business I guess.
author: Palmer B.

description: Prob the worst place ever.  Incompetent people and the worst customer service ever.  No wonder they only cater to tourists - chumps
author: Jesse L.

description: Love this place! It's almost like an oyster express without the ridiculous long line of hog island. We passed by on our way out of the Ferry building to have a little cheese and bread on the pier and behold! Pretty little shucked oysters just beckoning me. At $2 a pop, I'm in! The oysters of the day were delicious Royal Miyagis, sweet and bright. Yum!
author: Jamie M.

description: I tried the New England Clam Chowder and it was ok. Nothing to brag about. I also tried the Crab Quesadilla which was excellent. I love Quesadillas and this one was by far superior in content. Fresh crab meat with roasted peppers and carmelized onions with the right amount of cheese. If you are ever in the marketplace give them a shot. The customer service is great and the food is pretty good too.
author: K V.

description: Crab breakfast burrito was deeeeelliiccciiouusss!!! Coming from San diego where burritos are abundant, this crab burrito was a must try. It had yummy warm fresh fluffy eggs, crab meat galore, some cheese and other deliciousness and a soft tortilla. It would be ten times better, however, if they added french fries... California burrito style.
author: Minnow N.

description:
Food - a little pricey but it was alright, nothing special.

Now onto the seafood.  It is quite difficult to find fresh fish in the grocery store.  Safeway, Raileys, none of those got nice looking fish.   i was desperate and decided to check out SF Fish Company for their seafood selection for dinner.

Now, not all the fishes they offer look super fresh, but some look significanly fresher than the others.  So I picked those instead.

I tried the Opah filet first, found a nice recipe online, and the fish turned out super delicious.  It's taste like a Ahi Tuna but with slightly fishier taste.  Very good and very fresh! 

Next I tried the Sword Fish filets, again, found a recipe online, the fish look very fresh, and it was super tasty.  This became the BF's favorite fish, so for sure, i will return for some more sword fish!
author: Gigi T.

description:
After having some oysters from Hog Island Oyster Company,  I walked by here and decided that I should try some more.  They were $1.50 each so not only were they $.50 cheaper but they were bigger!  Too bad they didn't taste as good.

You tell the guy how many you want and unless you tell him specifically which ones in the bucket you want, he will just grab a bunch for you.  I'm not sure how he decides.  There are little jars of cocktail sauce and super fresh, super strong horseradish--just a little of this goes a LONG way.  I can't stress that enough.  The oyster itself just didn't have the ocean-water, ocean-fresh taste to it.  

I tried some of my friends clam chowder and it was bland and didn't taste much of any seafood.  For the good stuff, go to Fisherman's Wharf.  Nothing beats the clam chowder in bread bowls there.
author: Shannon L.

description: I think next time I should probably ask for a sample. Either I don't know what Jambalaya is supposed to taste like or they don't know how to make it. The seafood jambalaya was without a doubt the strangest jambalaya I've ever had. It was very, very dry and underseasoned. And there wasn't anything resembling tomato in the dish. I think seafood fried rice would have been more descriptive. I should have picked up one of the containers of sushi sitting in front of the register. They looked far more appealing.
author: Paul K.

description:
I got bored so I went to San Francisco for a day.  Not really...it's more like 6 hours and 30 minutes.  What to eat for lunch?  The plan was to eat oysters but I ended up at this nemo place.

I ordered halibut sandwich and gumbo.  The place was small and it looked more like a market than a restaurant.  

Halibut Sandwich: omgosh...the best fish sandwich I've ever had in my life.  Seriously I am not exaggerating.  The filet of fish was stuffed inside yummy bread with tasty sauce.  The sauce was pretty amazing.  I ate the whole thing in minutes.  I wanted second but didn't have enough time.  5 stars.
Gumbo: not my favorite gumbo.  It's kinda watery and where is the seafood?  I ate little pieces of seafood...maybe someone ate it and gave me the soup =P  2 stars.

I really like that place.  Nothing special about it...just a typical small restaurant but it did give me time to be alone.  I felt like I was on a mini vacation and I was enjoying my time there.

4 stars.

San Francisco Fish Company was yummylicious!!
author: Maggie C.

description: I've only been here twice and have only had the gumbo. It's pretty good. The soup has a nice taste to it, and has a decent amount of seafood. For about 10 dollars, you get a pint , which is the perfect size for lunch.
author: Stanley S.

description:
Crab cake sandwich was SO good - the cake is dense and rich, and reminded me of falafel with the thick fried exterior and warm inside. Really just great, with a super soft roll and spiced coleslaw to shovel on top. I also ordered gazpacho and was blown away by the freshness of the flavors - a great compliment to the sandwich. 

I seriously cannot stop thinking about that meal.
author: Vanilla P.

description:
You lost a customer guys!  I bought various fish then also asked if the whole squid had been cleaned/gutted.  I was told they were not and so asked the guys behind the counter if they could clean 4 squid for me.  There were about 5 people behind the counter, none apparently very busy with anything, but I was told NO - we don't prep fish for the customers, because "it takes too long".  I was the ONLY customer in the place.  How can a high end, expensive fishmonger or butcher not handle very basic prep for customers, especially when there are no other customers in the store??

Will not be going there again.  Mollie Stones or the great fish place in the Mission for me - better service; better value.
author: julie w.

description: This place has a good selection of seafood at a premium price.  I really like having the occasional fish sandwich there for lunch (I work nearby).  I am surprised that they do not offer what most of the local clientele wants:  A simply grilled fish, with a side salad and white or brown rice.  We love fish, but only having the option to eat it fried or between two huge pieces of bread means it is only once in a great while type of treat (too heavy for lunch).  If there was a healthy fish plate, I personally would eat here 3 times a week minimum.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Omgggg the crab cake sandwich...!!! Christmas in my mouth!!:) loved ittttt... yum yum yum


Will be back for more! Courteous service!
author: Monica M.

description:
I was given a recommendation to come here for their breakfast burritos. I was so excited. At $13-15 a burrito, it's definitely pricey, but my company was sponsoring so I didn't care.

I pre-ordered the day before to have the burritos made first thing the next morning and I would pick it up at opening. The burritos came out pretty quickly though I had to wait 15-20 minutes for them.

I brought them back to the office to eat. While eating and tasting my first bite, I just couldn't help not loving it. It had dungenness crab inside with cheese and egg and it just had no flavor. All the hot sauce in the world didn't make it better. They should have added more seasoning and salt to the burrito itself.

It was also extremely greasy. I needed so many napkins to catch the grease, and I'm not even sure why it was greasy??

Surely disappointed and I will not try it again.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
you can always rely on the san francisco fish company for a delicious, fresh and affordable lunch. they're quick to get you in and out during the lunch rush and are conveniently located inside the ferry building.

items i'm known to nosh on:
-crab quesadilla
-ahi poke
-seaweed salad
-volcano sushi roll
-seafood bisque
author: Mandy A.

description: How are you serving Basa (The basa fish, Pangasius bocourti, is a species of catfish in the family Pangasiidae. Basa are native to the Mekong and Chao Phraya basins in Indochina.) fish in your "fish n chips" you should be ashamed having the ocean in your back yard. I also had the lobster and chowder, the scallops and chips and everything was mediocre at best. I did enjoy the Clams and oysters being served on the half shell but that thank god you guys had no hand in the preparation of them. lucky for the tourist in the area or else you would not survive.
author: Victor G.

description:
$2 raw oysters. Yum!! Oyster po'boy was tasty . Great coleslaw! Their award winning Seafood gumbo as their sign said was not even close to award winning. Sorry don't know who the judges were but I've had much much better. Next time I go back I will try their lobster roll to see how it compares to my little other place in Half Moon Bay.

Only down side is minimal seating but that's the norm in all the eateries located here inside the ferry building.
author: Ms. T.

description: Best oyster po' boy!  I try this where ever it's offered and have found SF Fish Company's to be the best... plus the side of cole slaw is very tasty.  I'm just a few blocks from the Ferry Building and this is one of my go to places.
author: J. Z.

description:
Oh boy, does this place stank.  Stank with a capital Stank. 

I ordered fish tacos, their special of day, and their "award winning" seafood gumbo.  I was excited to try the fish tacos and after two bites, I didn't want anymore.  The taco skin was thick and dry.  The fish was fried and dry.  The salsa verde sauce tastes like it came out of a jar and for that matter, I've had better salsa verde out of a jar.  This has been the worst tasting food I've had at a restaurant this year probably.  The gumbo was okay.  I'm not sure what kind of award very okay gumbo wins.  

And I had to wait 15 minutes!  Why does it take so long to make their special of the day and to fill a cup with already made soup?  This place was not busy at all.  How long would I have had to wait if this place was busy?
author: Joe G.

description: Gross clam chowder, pretty flavorless like eating gruel. I wish they used better quality ingredients. U should probably go to hog island no matter how long the wait.
author: Joy C.

description:
I'm a transplant New Yorker, so take that for what it's worth.

However, I don't think it's asking a lot to be served what you order. Especially when what you order and pay for is 20% more expensive than what you actually end up getting.

Also, if your cooks/counter staff don't know the difference between fish, they probably shouldn't be working at a fish market.

Two stars because one of the dudes was super friendly, and the sandwich wasn't inedible.
author: Claire W.

description: Bought several pounds of mussels.  The guy bagging them up had his back to me so I didn't get a look at the mussels. Got them home--had to throw at least a third of them out. Some were flat out broken open; the others were just open and stayed open even when tapped. Bought more at Safeway for $2 less a pound and every one of those was perfect. Shocking lack of quality and won't be back to SF Fish Co.
author: Kristen F.

description:
Fish tacos are horrible. 
Damn you tourist trap; I've been got again!
author: Luke H.

description: I enjoyed the soft shell crab sandwich. Size wasnt too puny. Prob just right. Only $10.95. Will try their "award winning" seafood gumbo next time?!
author: David C.

description: I really like the low key character of this restaurant.  I had never been to San Francisco and went to the Ferry Building to check out the center and walk the piers.  Hog Island Oyster had a long line that you had to wait outside in, meanwhile this place had no line and was indoors.  It meant I had more time to peruse the other shops, so we went with this place.  We ordered the specials of the day, as we figured this meant the fish was fresh.  My mom purchased the swordfish sandwich with pesto and I had the sea bass sandwich.  We split a cup of crab gumbo as well.  The Allagash Pale Ale we split was smooth and perfect with the food.  It was a brand we'd never had, so we gave it a whirl.  The crab gumbo was spicy and rich, and though there wasn't tons of crab in it, it was flavorful as it was.  The swordfish sandwich was stacked with filets and the fish was so fresh and tender, the pesto a perfect topping.  My sea bass had a great sear on the edges, crispy and flavorful.  Their coleslaw side is nothing to get excited about, but it was good, too.  Not too watery or peppery or bland. The buns they put their sandwiches on are kind of like a torta bun. It was chewy and a little sweet, with a golden-brown smooth gleam on the top.  It was held up well to the weight of the fish!  I was extremely happy with this place.  There weren't many places to sit, but we got two bar stools and were able to people watch for a little bit.  The oyster bar was extremely popular as we saw, but we didn't try them.  Definitely an idea for next time.  Try this place - so worth it!
author: Kathryn T.

description:
*Review for oysters only*

Oysters are $2 each here. A little pricey but these are the freshest, tastiest oysters I've had in SF! They had a variety of small oysters, large oysters, and clams. I don't remember the actual names but the small ones are sweeter and the large ones are saltier. I prefer the small ones.. SOOO good with all the fixins! They have the traditional lime, tabasco, cocktail sauce, and horseradish sauce. 

I love the front door oyster setup. Wherever I go for oysters in SF, there's usually a wait but not at SFFC. You can get your oyster fix in a jiffy here! Just pick out which ones you want and they'll throw them on a plate for you right away. Who doesn't love instant gratification?
author: Helen L.

description:
$2 for fresh shucked raw oysters on the half shell, sittin' pretty on a bed of ice.. 

today: 1215
fresh, yes
wish they were a bit 'beefier' and with more body.. smooth, refreshing
author: Jana C.

description: I ordered the Cod & Chips special, because my co-worker raved about it.  What I ended up with is a piece of fish that was like a fishy piece of rubber - it was extra chewy and inedible, and I had to throw it away.  I won't be eating there again.
author: Jeffrey R.

description: Walk by sampling and I tried the raw oysters & softshell crab po boy sandwich. Enjoyed both highly.
author: SJ F.

description: Crab cakes? More like a brown mash of nasty. Over cooked and so dry.  Won't be coming back.
author: Michael P.

description: We had just gotten into town and decided to walk around. Found this place in the ferry building and decided it looked like it would be fast, authentic and good and oh boy was it! We shared the tuna burger and the clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl. Both were really yummy-my favourite was the soup which was creamy with lots of pieces of potatoes and clams without being fishy. The bread bowl was soft and amazing with the soup on or off it. The tuna burger was great and the balsamic dressing on it was the prefect compliment. Thoroughly enjoyed our lunch!
author: Jenna C.

description:
Dungeness Crab breakfast burrito review!  I had a craving for a breakfast burrito and noticed they had all kinds of funky options at the SFFC so I went for the dungeness crab.  The crab itself was pretty good, but the burrito is a bit on the smaller side compared to an average b'fast burrito you might get in SF.  Also the egg was made into a patty that was folded into the burrito which is not a style I enjoy as much.  If you like the egg-as-omelette-folded-into-your-breakfast-burrito you'll be pleased, but i prefer scrambled eggs that are still fluffy and light instead of matted down.

Anyhow, the other ingredients added flavor but there wasn't quite enough of them for my tastes.  I know the crab should be the primary flavor but it didn't all come together for me.  Oh well!, maybe the salmon one would have been a better choice - i'll try that next time!
author: Gene X.

description: Really liked my non-greasy, wheat tortilla wild shrimp quesadilla for $11. Was tasty, not too greasy. Don't like being nickel and dimed for bread and the "tax on service charge." Also, don't like surly service. We almost did take out and they just tack on extra fees for that too. The quesadilla was really tasty.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I came here to have lunch and do some grocery shopping. I was feeling mussels and purchased 2 lbs from here for dinner. I went with the lobster bisque for lunch, which was pretty bad. I was brought up asian and I was always told to finish everything on my plate. I could NOT finish that lobster bisque. It was heavily seasoned with some spice that made it bitter with each spoonful. There wasn't much of a lobster flavor and it was $11 down the drain.

I brought the mussels home and they weren't debeard. No biggie, I can do that myself. I had to throw out a few since they were already open. After cooking them in a tomato, shallot, saffron, sherry broth, I could see the mussels were not plump. 

I wonder if it's a west coast thing, but I thought they have a good selection of seafood. I've been disappointed so far after moving from Philadelphia where seafood is plenty, cheaper, and fresher.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: "Worlds famous" seafood gumbo was probably famous for the amount of oil on the top of the soup when you open up your cup. After draining the thick layer of oil, it was pretty good, but not amazing.
author: Sandeep K.

description: Don't eat here , the worst food ever.  Their jambalaya served staled & cold - as if they just took the left over out of the cooler and charge s you premium $$$$$ for it.
author: Khai B.

description:
I'm surprised that this place isn't rated higher than 4 stars. 

I've had their raw oysters and raw clams and they are delicious. 2 dollars for a clam/oysters was worth it in my opinion. They were sweet and of decent size. They were fresh and creamy, almost perfect. I like them with lime/lemon juice and a bit of Tabasco sauce. 

Definitely a place you have to stop by if you love seafood. Usually spend about 20 bucks on these little shellfish.
author: Chris T.

description:
The food at this location is decently served.  Prices are okay considering the average pricing of seafood in nearby restaurants.  We had the soft shell crab po'boy, which was pretty flavorful.  They serve it on fresh acme bread, which is a bakery next door.  The cod and chips were average.  Cod was not seasoned and fries were a little to salty.  

I would have given more stars if I didn't find a small piece of hair in the tartar sauce, which we had replaced.  I was also not impressed to observe the handling of the oysters at the front of the shop.  The guy serving had on gloves, which should mean it is cleaner.  However, he had on the same gloves when handling money, sweeping the floor, touching the bottom of the sweeper, garbage can and then the oysters.  Something tells me that just isn't right.
author: E C.

description: Good place for Steamed mussels and oysters on the half shell without the wait.
author: Yelp R.

description:
"Pretty sure that fish isnt coming from the bay"

A really solid special of the day fish sandwich.  While i've never gone out of my way for one, it was a solid choice for lunch when i worked on 1st pier (years ago)
author: Oleg H.

description: I have had a number of positive experiences here, both as a lunch consumer and a fresh seafood buyer (for home consumption). I even have bought a half-dozen live lobsters from them for a BBQ once upon a time... I have enjoyed my many meals which have consisted of various sandwiches, fish tacos, fish and chips, and my recent discovery- their ahi poke- which I am a big fan of.  The fresh fish has always been of high quality, and I rate their fish counter as one of the better ones in SF- I prefer Swan's and Bryan's, but outside of those- SF Fish Company is equal or better than all others that come to mind.
author: Andy S.

description:
If you haaaaave to come here, GET THE DUNGEONESS CRAB BREAKFAST BURRITO! It's the best among their breakfast/brunch specials.

But like everything in the Ferry Building, foods are overpriced and meager. This place is mostly for the tourists....
author: Rose W.

description:
Bought a piece of fish here... Looked fresh, but was definitely not fresh when I got home and was able to inspect it more.

Raw oysters were average at best... but definitely not worth spending your money here....
author: D T.

description: I've never seen an oyster establishment wash the oyster liquor out before. The shucker opens the oyster and proceeds to rinse that delicious liquor from the oyster before laying them out for presentation. Who does that?
author: D M.

description:
One of my favorite places for my raw oysters and raw clam fix. You might think $2 for an oyster or clam is expensive, but I'd rather have quality over quantity. When I come I usually spend about $16-20 just on oysters and I'm always craving for more. 

The oysters are always fresh and creamy. With multiple sauces for the oysters and clams such as cocktail sauce, lemon juice, horseradish, vinegar, they can only make them taste better. 

Everytime I come to the ferry building this is the first place I head to and i'm always wanting more.
author: Sean W.

description: Craving some seafood, I made the trek on over to the Ferry Building for lunch. I stumbled upon this spot and ordered the fish and chips. Man, that meal hit the spot! A really good portion size too for the $15 it cost. 4 pieces of fish and lots of fries. I would definitely return to try more items on the menu.
author: Greg J.

description:
I was surprised to see this fishy fish shop serve prepared food for lunch.  Only ate here once, but wasn't terribly impressed.  A fish shop's competitive advantage should be freshness and they can exemplify that with simple preparations.  Fancier renditions should be reserved for real restaurants that actually execute well.

Lobster Burger: The term burger is a gross misnomer.  Burger implies that the patty is all or mostly meat.  This was more like a "cake", similar to a lower quality crab cake, where most of the substance is fillers.  I think I tasted some lobster, but the bits were so fine it was hard to tell.  The sauce and bread were nice.  This would have been a kick-ass crab sandwich, but it fails as a lobster burger... I just expect more from that noble crustacean.
author: Adam B.

description:
Came here during the Ferry Building Farmer's Market.

$2 for raw claws or oysters.

The pink clams were so meaty, with the fresh aftertaste of clams.
The oysters were hearty. Two variations.

Full condiment offerings: cocktail sauce, lemon, horseradish, and Tabasco. Knowledgeable staff to help with your decision, or for $2 each, just try them all.

Big fan of fresh seafood. This place is the place to go!
author: Jason S.

description: The fish and chips were awesome! Shared it with my kids and they loved it! Comes with everything... fork, ketchup, tartar sauce, napkins, and if you take it to go, they put in a nice box. You have to go try for yourself!
author: Kong V.

description:
I walked into the Embarcadero looking for a place for lunch. Passed by the SF Fish Company and was very impressed with the quality of fish. Asked the young lady behind the counter which one of these she preferred: Fried Oyster Poor Boy or Fish and Chips. Her answer: Fish and Chips and I am glad I ordered it.

I can't recall that I have ever had better F&C. The batter was delicate and the fish was so fresh, it must have been caught that morning. Plentiful serving size and good "chips" made for a superb lunch. 

The dining area was tiny but clean and I enjoyed watching all the tourists wandering through Ferry Building #1. Finished my lunch with a "dessert" of a few raw oysters...yummy! I will be back for F&C next time I am in SFO. 

4 stars only for the dining area. There is nothing they can do about it and it is part of the appeal. Sit at the little tables and eat lunch with some people from all over the country. Enjoy!
author: Jorge d.

description:
Here is the deal with this place, short and sweet:
1. Shitty service
2. Really good food- crab melt was one of the best I have ever had, good chowder as well
3. Great scenery of the bay.
4. A little overpriced.
author: Jim B.

description:
You'd think that combining "San Francisco" and "Fish," this place would be a no-brainer for good food, right? Instead, we ate a mushy crab cake so overpowered with parsley that I couldn't even begin to taste the crab, and a cup of the thickest, blandest clam chowder I've ever had. It was enough to stave off the hunger pangs long enough to arrive at our next feeding trough, but wasted money, calories, as well as the commodity that proved to be the most valuable on our trip: stomach capacity.

4/14/2011
I should mention that the above is a review for a visit we made in 2010 that is currently posted to my blog.  I just got a message from Allen at San Francisco Fish Company who wanted to apologize for the meal that we had.

I appreciate that kind of attempt at service recovery, so I wanted to make sure that it was clear that my review was from an experience a year ago.  If Allen's level of effort to reach out and talk with a customer is not being replicated in the kitchen, things may well now be different at San Francisco Fish Company.
author: Ryan C.

description: Fish tacos were good.  Needed more sauce. The fish seemed a bit bland.  Clam chowder was watery
author: George C.

description: I guess it is okay to feel like a tourist every once in a while.  What can you say it is hard to over come how beautiful this city really is, to be able to sit next to the water, people watch, see ships and boats and have a great lunch.  Great bread, chowder, salmon, seafood stew, crab sandwich and the venerable crab louie.  All prepared perfectly, only negative was a little more pricey due to a heavy tourist spot of course and portions were a little smaller but still hard to beat!
author: BGinLove B.

description: Love coming here when I visit the Ferry building, they always have great seafood (Usually get the clams and mussel combo in pesto broth yummmm) and their Manhattan chowder is really good here too! Also, they had fresh watermelon juice and it was delicious :P
author: Alice S.

description: We were in he Ferry Building to do some shopping and when we found out the place we intended to have lunch was fully booked, we stopped by here and had our lunch. My aunt and I both ordered crab cake sandwiches, which came out fast and fresh. It was very good and definitely hit the spot. They also had a nice guy out selling oysters and clams, so I had a few oysters, which were okay - I've had better. My main complaint with this place would be the seating area. I know they don't have a lot of room to expand but the place is pretty cramped and stuffy. Ah well. Still worth stopping by for a bite to eat.
author: Nikki I.

description:
There is so much different stuff to try when you're in the Ferry Building so walking around I decided on SF Fish Company because they had breakfast burritos and other dishes that typically have meat but seafood instead!

During lunch it gets really packed so when I ordered food I had to go sit right outside the Ferry Building as their are tables by the Sur La Table. 

I ordered the crab quesadills which game with guacamole and I finished every piece!  I'll totally try the breakfast burrito next time!
author: Anya R.

description:
If you read my reviews, you know that I'm a pescetarian so SF Fish Company may seem like the PERFECT place.  Hrmm, I won't be so quick to write this place off, but their take on the Nicoise salad just didn't do it.

For about $9 I got: a lot of greens, hard boiled eggs, a couple grape tomatoes, and a pile of fish that was cold and very tough.  I know it was in the grab-as-you-go refrigerator, but it just didn't taste fresh.  The ratio between the fish and the overwhelming amount of lettuce was obviously out of balance.

I may come back since the Ferry Building is so close to work, but for now, SF Fish company is just aiight.
author: Alvina W.

description:
I wanted a tasty snack on the go to tide me over until dinner so I picked up some New England Clam Chowder and some seaweed salad. It was the perfect size to whet my appetite (as well as the BF's as he also picked up a hot dog nearby). 

I was eyeing the guy who was shucking fresh oysters in front but next time, I'll just go for a few of them.
author: Julia W.

description:
I had a delicious opah sandwich with chimichurri sauce.  I loved the ACME roll they serve their sandwiches on, nice and soft.  The sauce slightly overpowered the flavor of the fish so in the future, I might ask for them to go light on their toppings.  

It wasn't an overly-generous portion but considering how much else I eat when I'm at the Ferry Building, that's a bit of a blessing.

Nice folks too!
author: Shauna F.

description: I was hoping that they possibly carried more smoked fish items but alas, they only carried salmon. The fresh selection is pretty nice but it's actually the frozen that caught my attention. Bricks of salt cod, fish stocks, and whole slew of other things that a normal home cook would take forever to make. They also have a decent menu of items lunch. too bad I was already full and didn't get to sample a po boy or some shellfish.
author: Kim N.

description:
Lowest designation.

I was here before a while ago and they did a decent job, nothing special.  I returned recently to face sheer insult for me and my friend.  The cashier was clearly offended when I bought two bottles of water after she had just filled the plastic pitcher.  How could I?  

Her attitude throughout the transaction was deplorable.  We requested a different sauce on one of the sandwiches because my friend did not want anything spicy- and again, it was like we were just the most ruthless of customers for requesting anything.  I tried to ask a question from a guy relaxing behind the counter, and he totally ignored me.  The lady behind the counter apparently knew how insulting she was being when she asked us- 'so do you want your money back'?  Thanks for offering- yes.  We didn't eat there and won't return.

I am amazed that they can stay in business with staff like that.  Oh, and to top of your dish, they put the receipt directly on top of or in your food- their signature, I guess.

No apologies upon my confronting her in front of her manager.  Just "you insulted me first".

If you go here, expect the very real potential that the staff will be offended at your presence.

And, in regard to the comment from 'Allen K.':
  I cannot accept your apology as you have given it.  While you claim you will "avoid such misunderstandings in the future", I will again state that this was not a misunderstanding.  Me and my friend were singled out, for whatever reason, and we were treated not just rudely, but with directly offensive behavior.  As I told the cashier that day, 'we do not deserve this treatment' and 'do you feel empowered by insulting your patrons'?  There are misunderstandings and then there is poor treatment.  There is intention and then there are actions.
author: Marc M.

description:
We have friends and family in the bay area and for whatever reason, it took a co-worker in LA to tell me to go visit some place that has oysters out in front in the Ferry Building...

So good! We walked the whole length of the building before finally deciding to nosh on lunch here shortly after our arrival into town.  We're big seafood fans, but finding adequately priced fresh seafood is always a task outside of Asian influenced cuisine-- so paying $8-10 for a fresh sandwich didn't seem unreasonable when I have paid way more in the past. 

We had the softshell crab poboy and the grilled mahi with pesto aioli.  Both incredibly tasty.  The raw oysters out front was a definite luor for me, with lemon juice and cocktail sauce ready at hand sitting on ice.  Such  sweet little morsels! And I was especially happy that my bf who had never had a raw oyster before felt inclined to partake in my gastronomical quest--he loved it. :)

And I was happy to see that they had may delicious looking items in their display cases, including lobster broth, crab broth, and Squid Ink (?) wow. Growing up near Ports of Call in LA, it was a nice to see so many smoked items for sale in a clean little shop. We definitely will come back!
author: Christina A.

description: One of the more solid lunch spots along the Embarcadero. I can't speak to the clams or the oysters, but the sandwiches and breakfast burritos are worth the trip. The breakfast burritos don't look that big, but they are dense and filled with plenty of seafood. They do the job at lunch. The crab cake sandwiches are similarly filling and tasty. On my last visit, the sandwich had not come out after ten minutes, so one of the employees gave me a complimentary bowl of chowder and explained that they had just run short of bread. I appreciate touches like that. I'll be back
author: Taylor C.

description: Service wasn't friendly. *Mussels were horrible* but squid, halibut, clams and scallops were delish. Wish each service person had their own tip jar. It migh make f or better service kinda like Katz deli in NYC.
author: Emm C.

description:
This review is based on the ready made food, not the fish market.
Ordered steamed mussles and shrimp po boy. 
Mussles were perfectly cooked, juicy and tasty. Just added lemon and hot sauce for my preference. 
Shrimp po' boy had a nice crunch and a tasty sauce to accompany it. 
Would definitely recommend people to try their mussles(",) They do have fresh oysters and seating.
Hopefully one of these days I'll buy something from their fish market as they do have a wide selection.
author: Anna P.

description:
I liked that I could get small portions. I tried smoked herring salad, salt-cured salmon salad, smoked salmon "candy," and seaweed salad.
The smoked herring salad was the best of the bunch. The seaweed salad and the "candy" were too sweet for me to enjoy as lunch items. The salt-cured salmon was too raw for my tastes. But the smoked herring hit the spot.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Terrible. We had a swordish and a salmon sandwich. Greasy fish, hamburger bun... We wanted to uneat it once we were done.
author: Charles L.

description:
My friend and I decided to venture to the Ferry Building to get lunch today and after browsing all the little shops, we settled on the San Francisco Fish Company. We asked the woman taking orders about a few of their offerings and were assured that two of our picks: the crab quesadilla and the crab cake sandwich were her favorites and delicious! 

When I opened by crab cake sandwich though, I was horrified by the pool of oil that had formed at the bottom of the wrapping. The sandwich may or may not have tasted good, as I was so overwhelmed by the oil that it was all I could taste! My friend noted that while her quesadilla had plenty of crab meat, the oil and cheese were also overwhelming. 

The side of fries that we ordered was quite sizeable, but it also lacked any flavor, though, thankfully, it was the least greasy item that we ate!

Overpriced, overgreased and overhyped! I shall not be returning here.
author: Maria G.

description:
Seared tuna burger. "Seared" is the operative word here but my tuna was not seared but overcooked. And for an $11 price tag, you'd think the portions would be larger with something more than shredded iceberg lettuce strewn amidst the non-seared tuna. I was not happy to douse my poor tuna in Tabasco just to get some flavor in my meal. 

Two stars since it's in the cool Ferry building and they were friendly.
author: Rajiv S.

description:
After reading favorable reviews for the oysters and po boys, I am considering the fact that I simply ordered the wrong thing.

The Dungeness crab breakfast burrito was small for its price and unimpressive in flavor.  Of course, I understand that crab is an expensive meat, but surely, ten dollars should have paid for more than the few slivers I unearthed in my toddler-sized burrito.

The burrito ingredients, which featured crab, egg, avocado, and cheese, provided a bland combination that was forgettable.  I attempted to slow down each successive bite to appreciate the flavors, but there was no depth to enjoy.

The fries could have also used some distinctive seasoning.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Recently started eating meat again after 6 years and SF fish company has been able to help me in the transition to delicious meat.

They fully disclose where their fish comes from keeping the environment in mind.  The staff is knowledable when I asked them what was local to California so I can make educated choices when it comes to selecting fish.  Although the selection is small, the fish are quite good.

I haven't tried any of the pre-made food yet, I've only bought from the fish counter.

I suggest referring to their website to learn more about where their fish comes from.
author: Kameron K.

description:
I ate at Fisherman's Wharf for the first time in years. 
  Craving crab cake, I ordered one from the booth. And nearly cried. 
  $3.50 for a cold oily tiny patty of batter (with maybe 1% crab meat). 

And then I had a crab cake sammy and San Francisco Fish Company and nearly hugged the guy at the counter. 
  Huge crab cake. Filled with crab meat. And hot. 
  Yummerific.
Love me my fried seafood. 

Stupid Fisherman's Wharf. 
Thanks for reminding me of why I avoided you for years. 
I thought it was because of the tourists. But now it's for the food as well.
author: Vic C.

description:
hmmm. So many delicious looking items. Wish they were more helpful in helping me decide what I want to try, since everything on the menu sounding good! Yet not one person asked me if I needed assistance (wasn't busy, came during the week). I checked out the oyster lady but she didn't reel me in. I walked by several times checking the oysters out; she definitely knows her locals because she greeted them by name & joyfully helped them out. Me, the Mountain View land lubber - I'm on my own sorry oyster self. So I passed.
 I love seafood & so checking out the specials, I settled on the lobster chowder (no price marked but I had high hopes.) Guess I should've asked what was in it because while I will say, it was a tasty broth; for $6.50 that is exactly what I got: a tasty broth with a very, very, very few pieces of lobster. Not creamy, but watery, but yes it had taste. And this was a small cup. I was given a small bag of oyster crackers but at one look, these crackers would've overwhelmed the small cup I had. I tossed the spoon, set the crackers aside & *sucked* up my $7.05 cup of lobster broth (that's w/tax) & moved on. My mantra: too many other foodie options to try.
Oweeeee!!!
author: Kathi H.

description:
Sunday Walk Event...

I was standing in line for hog oyster, but the line was too damn long and took too damn long....

So we tried the Fish Company... was seated right away... that felt great...
still ordered oysters... and yes oyster is delicious.... but then again... they are either good or old and nasty... not much middle ground for them...
we also had crab salad... it was good... wish it came with a piece of bread... but that cool...
maybe...

service was excellent.....
author: Mike K.

description: I came here today for lunch, and ordered the soft shell crab po'boy.  I think they should be embarrassed to serve such a sandwich that is all bread and one ounce of crab.  Seriously, and I am a small person who eats small portions, but this was just ridiculous, not substantial at all.  Oh and on top of that I got sick after eating this.  Not sure I'll be back here again.
author: S G.

description:
I'm not going to lie, the only thing I ever get here are the crawdads/crayfish/mudbugs/whatever may call them. There pretty good and hard to find in the city. I usually ask for a pound and some drawn butter and then go get a baguette from Acme bread then go sit outside and people watch or read a book while I eat my crawdads. If you do it like me and eat them with the bread it is a relatively inexpensive meal.

Also I have tried the seaweed salad, which is good (though more expensive per pound then the Korean Market I get it at and it tastes exactly the same). 

On Saturdays during the farmers market they have a table set up with oysters that are $1.50 each, a pretty good deal, though there selection is usually from out of state. They always have a sweet/creamy type and a more briny/oceany type. (I usually prefer the oceany). I have de-virginized numerous friends to oysters through the San Francisco Fish Company's oyster table. It would be nice if they sold local oysters for that cheap but Hog Island has cornered the market on that one selling their oysters at the farmers market for $2 a pop.

All in all not a bad place to eat. They know who I am now: Crawdad Girl, which makes it all the more fun to be a regular somewhere.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I had lunch here and ordered New England clam chowder in a sour dough bread bowl. It was the worst bread bowl I've ever had. The bread was icy cold, like a bitter glacier. The soup was wretched. It had almost no clam and was extremely thickened with starch. 

Maybe the other items on their menu good, but don't get the chowder and don't eat any bread. My stomach churns just thinking about the meal I had there.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Average price/size/taste for their shrimp breakfast burrito.

What I'll remember most is the response to my request for egg whites. No. That in itself isn't new, it was the rationale behind it. Apparently as part of Ferry Building policy, they don't throw away food. It's wasteful.

Which begs the question: Compost or my stomach? No difference, right?

I ate confused. And missing black beans.

Majority of you will rate higher.
author: Jason B.

description:
I have never eaten lunch here and I only have come for the seafood and fish stock, neither have I ever visited this place during lunch hour. Hence, I am only reviewing their Seafood selection, quality, etc.

I love getting my mussels here and I absolutely adore their fish stock. Whenever I order shellfish (which, by the way is around $5 per pound for the mussels), they always go thgouh each one, selecting the ones that are fresh and meaty. Since I've been shopping there, every mussel dish I have cooked turned out perfect. In other shops they just grab a bunch, shove them in the bag, and when you get home, you end up throwing out a few that are no longer fresh. Not here! I love this kind of attention to detail. And the mussels are meaty, fresh and taste of the sea. 

Their fish stock is also fresh and delicious, full of flavor. I am not the type to make my own stock, and I don't like to use canned or concentrated stocks, so if a recipe requires fish stock, I just zip on over here and get as much as I need. The service has been fantastic thus far and I've been one happy customer.
author: Yelena K.

description: I suspect this is a really great place BUT THEY CAN'T MAKE JAMBALAYA!!!!!!  Just had lunch  - Tuesdays are always Fat Tuesday and they make a few New Orleans (Cajun) style dishes.  Been to New Orleans many times and made Jambalaya many times.  Took a friend today and she's from Louisiana. What we were served was not jambalaya at all!!! It was over cooked bland mushy rice with two shrimp on top.   Awful!!! They may as well call it Eggs Benedict because it's not that either.  Despite all this, I believe it's probably got a lot of good things to eat.
author: Jayne H.

description: Oysters yum! Good service. Guy showed us how to pick creamy rich oysters. 2 bucks each for a fresh, refreshing  oyster .
author: Carrie T.

description:
Ferry Building is always a good lunch spot, where you can pick up something and then sit outside (benches out side the building as well as further north on the other side of the dock.)

SF Fish Company New England Clam Chowder was tasty with lots of clams and thick soup base.

And soaking in the sun while enjoying the soup overlooking the beautiful Bay Bridge makes you want to not go back to work!
author: T L.

description: I came across this place during my search for the ATM machine during the farmer's market. The oysters were so fresh and so delicious. I have to come back to try one of the po boys...
author: Dani D.

description: i went to the city for a fun day with my daughter. We had some oysters here and 2 hours later i was in severe pain and then was throwing up for hours. i notified them but they didn't bother to respond. Sad that i may never be able to eat an oyster again after this experience. Stay clear! Ruined our day of fun.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Oh.  I love this place.  I was there this weekend to visit some friends and they had $1.50 oyster special and OMG, I almost came on my pants enjoying their oysters and bread bowl chowder.  

I would so come here on a weekly basis if I ever live here. 

And yes, the myth about oysters is true :D
author: Ernie K.

description: nice place, fast service. a little short on the seating, alittle short on the quesadilla. not what i expected but still tasty.  hubby got gumbo, he liked it very much.  it was good and convienent, just a tad pricey. yes would be back to try other items. its all very fresh.
author: Lochin S.

description: Wow!  In a city filled with superior seafood this place is in the top rank. Has an oyster poboy that was better than Acme Oyster in New Orleans. Manhattan clam chowder was excellent...probably as good as I have ever tasted.  My wife has eaten hear many times and raves every time No table service but a very cordial staff. Only about 8 seats so try and get there early. This place runs circle around Hog Island.
author: Rick C.

description: We came in here for their soups after a cold day of walking around the farmer's market.  There were signs that said they had award winning best seafood gumbo.  It was just okay.  I preferred their clam chowder over their seafood gumbo.  The gumbo seemed a little bland and watered down.
author: Gordon C.

description:
I have been wanting a crab melt for a long time now. And it seems every time I try to find one I come up empty handed. I was led to believe this place had a crab melt. I was led astray.

So, I got the deep fried catfish sandwich for 7.50. Don't see much fried catfish in SF, a staple in my Southern hometown, so I ordered it. It gave me one of these: :(

The fish, while well-fried, was bland. The batter needed serious seasoning, and the tartar sauce tasted exactly like plain mayo. The bread was really forgettable, and the sandwich fell apart when I picked it up.

Doubt seriously I'll be back. (But I will peek at their menu for the elusive crab melt!)
author: Brittney G.

description:
I take issue with the tuna sandwich here.  Why, oh why would you ever serve good tuna any way but rare??!  I even asked when ordering to make sure it would actually be seared and not cooked all the way through.  Then I get the sandwich.  It is cooked virtually all the way through.  Maybe if you squint, you can make out some tiny sliver of red in the middle, but that might've been my wishful eye.  You also don't get very much tuna, which may be part of the problem.  You slap that thin sucker on the grill for 5 seconds and it's already on its way to medium well.  But, I must admit - it did taste good.  But oh it could have been so much better!!  

The fish and chips are decent.  Not too much batter, not too oily, pretty good cole slaw on the side - I only wish it came with more of it!

Prices are high for what you get, but par for the course in the Ferry Building.  Should probably leave it for the tourists, but I'm not sure where else to get a quick seafood snack/lunch in the area.
author: Leslie L.

description:
Eh.  tourist trap? Definitely disappointing.

I got the crab cake sandwich. The crab cake is MOSTLY IF NOT ALL FILLER - it tasted like a big bread crumb - I couldn't find any crab in the cake at all. The bread it comes on was really good (prob. ACME soft roll). It comes with lettuce and some sauce.  It also comes with a side of coleslaw which has a nice horseradishy taste. Its like 11 bucks.

The fish tacos were good. I wouldn't really recommend ordering tacos from a place like this - stick to a real mexican restaurant or taqueria. The fish was mahi mahi and they really needed some hot sauce or fresh salsa slathered all over them. The fish was good underneath all the cabbage. These were like 11 bucks. Not worth the money.

Seating is also very tight.
author: Chili B.

description: Okay, if you've passed by the SF Fish Co in the Ferry Building without having eaten there, I'm sure you're confused at the five stars. It looks distinctly unappealing, with oysters laid out over ice in front of the entrance, and beady-eyed fish glaring at you from the depths. We stopped by for lunch because of my hearty affection for seafood, and the crab quesadilla lived right up to my dreams. I wanted to order half the menu and can't wait to go back for some of their poke, or--once I figure out what a po'boy is--the softshell crab po'boy. The seafood was clearly fresh and full of flavor. The "servers" (people working behind the counters?) were cheerful. The prices are superbly low. If you're looking for cheap and delicious seafood, avoid the dreadful stands past Fisherman's Wharf, which serve up too-fried or mayo-drenched chunks of flavorless fish. SFFC is the way to go.
author: Koyel B.

description: I love their California rolls! There is so much crab meat inside each sushi that your meal is bang-for-your-buck. Also, there are eight of them in each tray so it really is quite filling. I also ordered their cod and fish entree and found the fries delightful - perfectly crispy and salty. The cod was also so soft but fried nicely. Service at the restaurant was really friendly too, but then again, I went there around 11:30AM before the lunch peak hit so the servers had some available time to deliver the food to my seat when it is usually pick-up.
author: Erica J.

description: I was browsing the shops and saw a self serve raw oyster bar and decided to treat myself.  I paid $2 an oyster and got one free from the sweet kid at the bar.  The oysters of the day were kumomato and very sweet and fresh tasting.  They had all the fixings; lemon, horseradish, cocktail sauce.  I was one happy girl.
author: Naida E.

description:
$1.50 Oysters

I think, "Wow! What a deal! I'll take 3!"

2 minutes later, i am outside, and I have already eaten 2/3...and I notice...a weird, squirmy, bug? animal? something?! on my third oyster. YUCK!

It went straight to the trash. Eew.
author: Misha F.

description: Pricy crab meat goes well with cup-o-chowder. Pleasant staff.
author: Inigo M.

description: Update March 2012: $24.50 for a crab melt and 50 cents for bread. The line has been drawn, and I'm afraid I'm done. My advice, go and buy the components (crab meat, cheddar cheese, ACME bread), and make this sandwich at home. I'm serious...that's what I did.
author: Barrett F.

description:
I don't need a bag, I said smugly to the cashier, gesturing to the bag I brought with me. Ok, he said as he handed me my salad. 

I put the salad in my plastic bag, whirled around and the salad slit through the bag and exploded onto the floor. A gang of tourists made various exclamatory noises as I stood paralyzed while flashing back on childhood ice cream adventures.

I guess I needed a bag after all I said, leaning over to clean up the mess. The cashier said don't worry about it as he handed me another salad. The backup cashier came out and cleaned up the salad mess. 

Thank you San Francisco Fish Company for giving me another salad (and not charging me for it) even though dropping it was clearly my fault. Thanks again for being so kind and understanding. Sorry for the mess.
author: Mitsi M.

description:
Who would have thought to order a Shrimp Burrito for brunch on the go in the Ferry Building?  Well luckily my brilliant friend did.  Honestly, this breakfast burrito was simply the tastiest burrito ever.  

This thing had so much going on.  The texture was amazing.  The hot omelette like egg oozing with hot cheese a hint of butter and slathered with creamy guacamole made you forget it is a shrimp burrito.  But then you take another bit and you have a nice sized shrimp in your mouth cooked to perfection.  Slightly salted to bring out the flavor, you can really enjoy the flavor of the fresh shrimp (almost slightly sweet).  Totally recommend it!!!
author: Shiho F.

description:
Since I had eaten at Delica the time before, I decided to choose something else in the Ferry Building and after walking up and down the arcade, I came to this locale. I had heard so much about the po' boys that I decided to see for myself what it was and since it was one of the specials, I settled for this place. 

If this place is a name to be respected on the subject, a po' boy is a sort of sandwich in a bolillo sort of roll (and if you were Mexican, you would know that a bolillo is a typical Mexican staple in the bread section, normally about 7 inches long). The shrimp was seasoned with paprika and other spices, kind of similar to Old Bay spice, but not as tangy, and extremely tasty. 

Regardless of the taste, I just looked at the sandwich and though "Ten dollars is a little steep for this." And as good as it was, the price just didn't sit well with me. I gave SFFC three stars for the size of the po' boy (I felt really denied, to tell you the truth...).

I washed away my cares with a bottle of San Pelligrino and all was good.
author: Fumiko N.

description:
The cashier was ringing me up when the register popped open and hit him in the pelvis. He pauses, looks up, and says, "It's a good thing I'm not a foot taller..." Haha, hilarious...

I love this place. The people are friendly and they offer all the seafood you could possibly want. I will end up in crustacean hell for eating so many sea creatures.

A ton of sandwiches under $10. The Lobster Burger could stand to have more lobster (but then again, what couldn't?). I need me some lobster cola...

Accepts credit cards (including AMEX).
author: Keane L.

description:
I was rather sadly disappointed with my soft shell crab po boy sandwich from the San Francisco Fish company.  

First off, I will note that it's reasonably priced for soft shell crab sandwich at about $9.30 with tax. 

However, they smear some kind of McDonald's sorta thousand island pinky dressing on the sandwich that does not go with the soft shell crab whatsoever.  Moreover, the bread they use for the sandwich is too thick...so each bite is more bread than what one might desire for a soft shell crab sandwich.  Soft shell crabs are rather delicate tasting things...it's very easy to overwhelm the taste, and that's what they have done at the San Francisco Fish Company.  They should consider using a regular sandwich bread, fry the crab so it's crispier, and use a traditional tartar sauce.  

I am doubly sad as I was so looking forward to this sandwich...soft shell crabs are not easy to come by on the West Coast since they are native to the New England area.  I guess that's what I get for being rather shellfish selfish in my disregard of the environment and eating gas guzzling food that's been shipped across the continent.

On an equally disappointing note, their tuna nicoise looks nothing like a tuna nicoise.  Everything looks glopped in some sauce.  And their other items are overpriced.
author: Sooj O.

description:
I originally wrote a nasty review of this place as a few others have, only to be notified by Yelper E.L., that I was mistaken by the name. The place to avoid is Ferry Plaza Seafood, which is the counter restaurant right next to SF Fish Co.

So, sorry about that. Avoid Ferry Plaza Seafood like the plague. 

SF Fish Co is a decent fish monger and butcher. I've picked up tuna and swordfish a few times and was well satisfied.
author: Philip M.

description:
My wife wanted me to pick up some fresh fish for dinner.   I came in around 5:15 PM and although there were 4 or 5 employees chatting and laughing jovially behind the counter, not one of those idiots thought it might be a good idea to come and help me out.    Finally some guy walked in and came to help me out, so I can only imagine that he was on a cigarette break or out back boning his girlfriend while I was standing there waiting for someone to sell me some fish.

The fish on display was tragic...  In fact the only non-shellfish on display was the halibut, and the clerk assured me it was fresh fish locally grown.   I bought slightly over a pound and it came to $22.  Ouch!   Next came the most comical display of incompetence I've ever seen... The guy twitched around nervously looking for plastic, or aluminum, or baggies... basically anything to wrap the fish in so he could send me on my merry way.    He looked around, perplexed, and couldn't figure out what to do.  He picked up a small plastic baggie which quite obviously wasn't going to come close to fitting the one pound piece of halibut.   All the while I'm thinking, "Am I on fucking candid camera?!?"   I was clearly getting frustrated so he took the fish, unwrapped, and threw it in a freezer bag (y'know those aluminum bags that are supposed to keep frozen things cool?)  He asked if I wanted ice in the bag and I acquiesced, thinking it might be a good idea to keep the fish cold.    He goes to the back room and comes back with a plastic baggy full of ice.   As he readies to put it in the bag, he says, "Oh, I better staple it," so he goes off to the cash register to staple my plastic baggy full of ice, comes back, and throws it in the freezer bag before sending me off on my not-so-fucking-merry way.

I get home.   The fish stinks.   My wife's a chef and says immediately that fresh halibut is not supposed to stink this bad.   Within minutes, our house is infested by sick noxious fumes emanating from this piece of fish.   Reluctantly, she still cooks it, making sure to cook the shit out of it.   She makes a beautiful white wine sauce in which she slowly simmers the fish.

Long story short:  took one bite, spit it out.   I got ready to throw the whole piece of fish out but my wife stopped me saying that our cats might enjoy it.    We put a little bit of fish in their bowl and they both ran away screeching.

That, my friends, is the San Francisco Fish Company.
author: David O.

description: Love this place.  We always find great shellfish and fresh fish to take home and cook.  They have great oysters too.  A little pricy, but it's the ferry building.
author: Kristen V.

description:
More like 4.75, let's round up. 
Fresh Fish: You absolutely can't beat this selection of wild, delicious fish.  It's expensive, yeah, but you can tell when you're eating a wild salmon fillet (versus the farmed, dyed-orange, scaly crap from Safeway) that it's worth every penny.  Staff will even give you cooking tips if you're new to cooking seafood. 

Eat there: GREAT lunch spot. Everything from the yummy fish sandwiches people are yelping about to huge portions of steamed muscles served in butter and garlic for between 7-8 dollars. Bargain!  Don't miss the curry, corn and crab chowder- flavorful, unique and generous on the crab.  Also don't miss the $1.50 fresh oysters served every Saturday during the farmer's market. 

Take out:  CANDY SMOKED SALMON.  Damn, skillet, damn. You'll say $26 a pound is too pricey. It probably is. But DAAAAAAAAAAAAM. And for about $5-6 you'll get 3-5 substantial pieces, and with a product this rich, it's plenty.

Only negative: on days too cold to sit outside, the limited seating can't accommodate the lunch-hour rush.  hit it up early or late for a glorious experience.
author: Jenni D.

description:
This old lady asked- me to stop coughing... wat a hag!

I almost died choking ...

I guess - soft shell crab wit soft bread is a deadly combination, wit the not so soft crab....  Next -  I will order the tacos!
author: swys -.

description:
Cold, wet and foggy day in SF...Put me in the mood for clam chowder and sourdough bread, so we decided to give SF Fish Company a shot and were pleasantly surprised.
