S.B. ordered a medium sized container of new england style clam chowder, we bought a twilight (lump of sourdough bread from Acme) and walked out to the giant bow and arrow sculpture on the Embarcadero to look out at the Bay Bridge while we enjoyed our lunch.

I didn't get to fully drink the soup since it has clam in it, but I did gobble up pieces of sourdough soaked in the soup.  They definitely do N.E. style clam chowder well.  It looked like it was thickened with potato rather than cream which I prefer, it was not too salty, and it had a very distinct and noticeable white pepper flavor which made it extremely delicious.

Clam Chowder + Sourdough + Bay Bridge + Fog = Quintessential SF...Love!
author: Burrito M.

description:
While wandering around, looking for lunch on a break at a client, I pop my head up and think "Hey, there's the ferry building. Must be something tasty in there!" -as a side note, do thoughts go in quotes?- I wasn't sure what I wanted or even how hungry I was, but I pledged to walk the length of the building before deciding. I almost stopped in to any number of places before reaching SFFC. The dealmaker was the Opah sandwich. Mmmmm, Opah! Brings me back to GREAT memories in Hawaii. Mama's fish house, sailing at sunset... and a whole lot of other not-so-appropriate-for-a-web-forum things! So I place my Opah order (don't you love assonance?) and wait by the counter. 5 min later, fishy goodness on soft bread arrives! Just the right amount of tartar sauce and seasoning. The fish was cooked perfectly, crispy edges with soft, juicy meat. 

If Race Street Fish (in San Jose) had an upper-class brother, this would surely be it!
author: Alex L.

description: For $10.50 I got the Shrimp and Fries basket to share with a friend and it was HUGE! The Shrimps were nice and big and yummy, not too much batter. The fries were good but plain, nothing exciting.
author: Karen T.

description:
I would say the only good thing we had that afternoon at The Fish Company was the free refill on soda and the bread.

I had the ahi tuna salad, boring, bland, and not worth the $18. Yuck!

My hubby had the crab sandwich,  over salted, bland and $17. Yawn..

We shared a bowl of clam chowder, which lacked the main ingredient, clams. How do you make a clam chowder with only 2 clams?

By the end of our disappointing meal we payed $50 and left not satisfied at all.

POO ON YOU SF FISH COMPANY!
author: Kelli H.

description: Came across this restaurant Saturday morning in the Ferry building .  My friend ordered the bay shrimp burrito which included avocados and eggs.  The shrimp was fresh and the tortilla was perfect.  The burrito was plenty for the both us to share.  We enjoyed this place so much that we returned for lunch another day and I ordered the pan seared tuna sandwich which was simply amazing!!!!  My friend ordered the crab quesadillas and I wasn't impressed much.  They had fresh oysters on display and I certainly regret not tasting them as I hear they are delicious!  I definately recommend this spot for a quick bite to eat.  I thought the price was average compared to the other restaurants in the area.
author: Ursula R.

description:
As a lunch spot in the Ferry building expect to spend most of that $20 in your wallet.
3 fish tacos = $12.05
Sure, 3 tasty mahi mahi tacos with tomatillo and lime salsa.  With shredded cabbage on toasted corn tortilla shells.
Mahi's not the most flavorful fish, but makes for a tasty taco if you dress it up nice.
I'm kind of still hungry though.
Maybe spend the rest of the 20 on some chowder.
author: Kev M.

description: Clam chowder tasted only like bay leaves. Nothing like clams... nor chowder. Service was good and fast
author: Rico R.

description:
Crab quesadillas - hella effin good!! Mussels - comes in a huge bowl, the sauce and wine is to die for. Swordfish [..]

I can go on nonstop about this place. It's hella good. I've tried everything (YES, everything). I eat lunch here almost daily.

Sometimes when I order two meals for myself, the management throws in the drinks for free (because the total cost of the meal is around 30ish bucks). 

It's a good place, I used to hate fish, now I love it. Props SF Fish Company.
author: Jey P.

description:
Went here for lunch and it was fantastic.  The lobster chowder is delicious and the oysters in the po' boy were perfect--crispy on the outside and melt-in-your-mouth delicious on the inside.  My friend had the raw clams and she said they were incredibly fresh and that the cocktail sauce was amazing.

If you're in the area, I highly recommend going for a quick delicious meal. I left completely satisfied and not overly full.
author: A J.

description:
It's a Friday during Lent and this Catholic school girl was looking for a fish-friendly lunch.  

Since the sun is finally shining, I wandered down to the Ferry Building for some fresh air and sunshine.  Per the usual, the line for Taylor's was 25 deep and not moving.  The grumbles in my tummy told me that I would not be waiting.  

I wandered inside and decided to try The SF Fish Company.   I love seafood like a fat kid loves cake, so I stared at all the fun items on the menu finding it hard to pick just one.   

I settled on the "seared ahi tuna sandwich" for $9.50.   So what went wrong?  It was like the 1984 Wendy's commercial "where's the beef?" except the question was WHERE'S THE TUNA!???

Ok, seriously kids, my tuna "steak" (as the man described to me" was BARELY a 1/4 of an inch thick.  Major bummer, because if you closed your eyes, the sando was pretty good - albeit over-cooked.  

For the extra $3 and (no joke) 3x the tuna, I will be going to Taylor's rather than the SF Fish Company for the next few Friday's of Lent.
author: Sho O.

description:
Oh my.....FRIED LOBSTER SANDWICH.
It's like....crab cake sammys all grown up.
Yummer yummer yummer yummer....

(I suppose there's no point on talking about the lack of seating being that we went on a Saturday morning....Eh. For such a good sandwich, you'll feel like you're floating on air and don't need a chair for your fat  derriere...)
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Finally ate lunch here - it's the best place to eat lunch in the Ferry Bldg. I had phenomenal potato leek fish chowder with a side of sesame seaweed salad and my husband had the fish and chips. The chowder was outstanding, flavored with fennel seeds. My husband's fish and chips was the best I have ever eaten - light, fluffy tempura like batter on the very fresh fish and perfect French fries. They have "Fat Tuesday" every Tuesday, where they serve gumbo, jambalaya and etouffee. 

Tried their gumbo - it's GOOD. We keep buying quarts of it and arm wrestling over who gets the last bits. YUM.

This is where we buy fresh fish, such as squid, halibut and local cod. The fish is labeled with origins and the fishmongers seem truthful when I ask how recently that particular fish arrived in their store. They have limited supplies of shrimp with the heads on (you need that for gumbo) and those tend to sell out early.
author: Vena V.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy!!!  We usually come here whenever we have a class in the city.  Walking to the Ferry Building during lunch hours is well worth it!  I always get their crab-cake sandwich & a white or red clam chowder - yes I justify by "saying it's ok to eat more at lunch...".  I'd also recommend their lobster chowder when available - it's creamy goodness you wouldn't want to miss!  It's so good that I'm actually willing to go for a run before stopping here for a meal....just so I won't feel guilty afterward.  :P  

Crab cake sandwich - nice & simple, crab cake cooked moist and seasoned just right topped with lettuce & tomatoes with their special sauce.  One amazing sandwich!!! Their chowders are chunky with plenty of clam pieces - yum yum!  Foods are served quick here so I'd recommend ordering your food and take it outside by the pier, find a nice bench and enjoy the view while eating your lunch!  Love it!  :D
author: Vivian W.

description:
I just came here for the first time today after my boyfriend had told me about the awesome fish sandwiches he'd been grubbing on the past few weeks.  I had the soft shell crab po boy.  It was super yummy--a bit oceany, but that's no complaint when eating fresh seafood. I did feel weird about eating an entire animal (carry over from my vegetarian days?), so I stopped a few bites short of finishing.

I ordered the fries, too, which were super yummy, skins on, with parsley sprinkled on top.  Malt vinegar tossed in made them unbearably good.

My dining partners got the Sante Fe crab cake sandwich and the halibut sandwich.  No complaints from anyone.  A ten dollar lunch, but well worth it for a Friday splurge after a week of brown bagging it.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Booyah crab quesadillas the way St Francis intended them to be made.  Served with a nice portion of fresh guac and coleslaw salad the lunch special gave the best of fresh boiled crab and cheese grilled in a nice whole grain tortilla, served over the counter in a basic boardwalk style takeaway open container.

The price tag, a tad higher than fast-food fare, is quickly forgotten upon the first bite into the crisp outer shell of this sumptuous lunch option.  Not for everyday but keep in mind for times when you have full sun, good friends to share with & a few quarter turns of the clock to spare.
author: Jim W.

description: Had the fish tacos and clam chowder here. Definitely liked it! There's a lot going on with the fish tacos, do don't go there on an empty stomach!
author: Analisa S.

description:
This place starts with it's owner, Allen Kuehn A very creative kind soul who brings only the freshest fish on the west coast including the famous Pike's market in  Seattle.
 As a chef myself it's all about quality and it does not get any better than this.
Allen has some of the best salads I have ever tasted. What a plethora of choices for seafood.  It's an event to spend a few hours in the ferry building. Al will hold your purchase until you leave the building to keep it fresh. Go there sample stuff , remember to have a good thing is to support a good thing.  Nice selection of beers also.
author: joe m.

description: Excellent fish monger who will prep fish how you want. They have good suggestions on how to prepare the fish when you get home. I stick with the local catch because I know it's fresh and they're open on Sunday, so I can walk over in the afternoon and pick up dinner.
author: Lefty R.

description:
Fool me twice, shame on me!  First visit was 2 1/2 stars (4 stars for food, 1 star for service), second visit was 1 1/2 (both food and service), so I guess that averages out to 2.

First time I had a delicious Halibut sandwich to go, but I really didn't like the fact that cashier gruffly informed me that the posted price of $7.50 (which already seemed like a bit of a reach) was "wrong" and that it was actually going to cost me $8.50 (plus tax, so a net price over $9)!  It took him almost five minutes just to TAKE my order because he was at a loss as to how to ring it up, so instead he set about erasing the posted chalkboard price and left me standing there, wallet in hand.  When he finally got back around to ringing me up, I asked if it came with anything and he said (verbatim) "a tiny thing of cole slaw."  Wow, that really pumps me up.  So I also got a verrrrrrrry small container of seafood orzo (which turned out to be delicious, but sheesh, THREE BUCKS?!).

Despite the expense and unpleasant service, the food was good enough to lure me back for a second visit, but I think that's it for me.  I had the sole sandwich special and--whew!--the posted price of $7.50 was actually the price I was charged.  But it was breaded and fried (and not very well) and seemed a lot more like catfish than sole because it was thick and veiny rather than thin and succulent.

With all the places to choose from in the Ferry Building alone, not to mention the FiDi, you'ld think they'd make an effort to do better.  But noooooo...wake UP, FiDis!  They are LAUGHING at you, all the way to the bank!
author: John D.

description:
I haven't actually bought the fresh seafood from here, but I have had their crab cake sandwich a couple of times - and I absolutely love it.  On occasion, I will treat myself to a pricier lunch - after all, what good is the money you earn if you don't splurge on yourself once in a while, right?  And what a way to splurge - both on a sandwich and on my diet.  A large, breaded patty of pure crab meat with just the right combination of spices, a creamy 'thousand island'ish' spread on top, tucked into a warm bun.  Yummy!

On a sunny day, sit outside on one of the many benches by the pier and look out at the beautiful city.  This is why we all work so hard - to live with views likes these and eat like this!

Since they cook up the sandwich on order, be prepared to wait a few minutes before getting your food.  You don't want to come here if you're in a lunch hour rush.  But if you do have the time, it's well worth the wait.
author: Denise M.

description:
Well, you would expect this place to be very unique and respectable.  Honestly though, they took approximately 17 min. to TAKE my order itself.  They kept referring me to their "other" counter... now, I don't what was up with that, because they took other people's orders... just not mine.  Finally, I went to another counter that took my order, even though it was actually the "pick-up" counter.  Finally after 30 min., I got my fish tacos that upset my stomach 1 hour later.  

Don't go here. :)
author: Labonee M.

description:
I once saw Bobby Bacala (Tony's bitch in the Sopranos) here.  I was super stoked, +1 star.  The Fish and Chips are average.  My favorite thing here is the salmon roll salad.  Yes, I know its iceberg lettuce but the simple combination of:

Iceberg lettuce
Cherry Tomatoes
Cucumbers
Oyster Crackers
Kalamata Olives
Salmon covered with black pepper

And a lemon vinaigrette dressing.

Let me tell you it's like a salad that Denny's could sell for 13 bucks!

Of course, you must prepare it and shake it up, don't eat like an amateur. 

Oh yea, the seafood here is pretty much the bomb.
author: Justin C.

description: First time today.  Went with a safe choice:  Fried catfish sandwich.  Very tasty and not greasy at all.  Definitely will go back and try other things such as the crab cake sandwich and the soft shell crab sandwich.
author: Josh L.

description:
i hate heavy breading on shrimp/prawns, and yet i love everything deep fried.  most of the time, the two don't get along, because most places bread the hell out of their shrimp, and all i taste is deep fried flour over deep fried flour!

but this place... it's like they know me!  their shrimp po'boy sandwich was super lightly breaded... almost as if they just dredged it in a well-seasoned flour right before frying, and the sauce was super delicious.  i don't normally like coleslaw, but i liked theirs!

while i waited in line to order, i caught a glimpse of the seafood salads in the case. omgyum! too much good stuff in this place, i just wanna eat everything!  they sell poke packets, complete with seaweed and seasonings.  i would probably never buy, but it was cute.
author: jennifer l.

description: Not many choices to get fresh sea food on a Sunday afternoon, luckily SFFC is a short drive from home. I picked up several pounds of fresh mussels and clams to cook for dinner. Great quality and selection is found here.
author: Steve S.

description: The best smoked herring salad ever.  In addtion, good selection of fish and owner, Alan, is very helpful.
author: WK C.

description:
Three words: Fish and Chips. 

I could leave it at that and my 4-star rating and let you fill in the rest; however, I like them so much I must rave a bit about their general wonderfulness. You get four or five pieces of fish that are nicely fried in a light batter. Then, to go with the fish, you receive cocktail sauce, the best tartar sauce I've ever had, vinegar, and ketchup to go with the very tasty fries. My co-worker likes to ask for the fries to be extra crispy, but I think they're just fine the way they are normally cooked. 

I'd give it five stars, but they're just a bit too pricey for that, at $9.50 a pop. Still, super tasty and totally worth the occasional financial and caloric splurge.
author: Katie I.

description:
I was in the mood for cooking some fish at home and decided to try this place. I decided to get some rockfish based on the recommendation of one of the employees. He told me what kind of fish it was, where it came from and his suggested way to prepare it. I thought the price was very reasonable for a fresh piece of fish. I will definitely be returning.
Good service!
Good location!
Fast!
author: Roger H.

description:
My husband and I really like going here. In fact, our 3 favorite merchants inside the Ferry building are all right by each other: SF Fish Company, Prather Ranch Meat, and Far West Fungi. 

Anyway, there's a guy at the Fish Company that typically helps us out (The one that wears glasses and is almost always there). He makes good recommendations and very reliable...we used to pre-order softshell crabs somewhat often and they were always ready as promised. One time there was a batch that wasn't so great when we picked them up and he suggested we not take them after all. We've had great experience with the quality and service here!
author: Mellie D.

description: My fish tacos were dry and bland.  The mahi mahi was fresh, but way overcooked. Even all of the (bland) slaw and salsa on top didn't make it any better. At least the portion was a good size. (Three well-filled corn tortillas for $12. Anywhere else, I'd say it was expensive, but what do you want--it's the Ferry Building.) If you still decide to try the tacos, I'd suggest some hot sauce and a fork. My cousin said he liked his fried catfish sandwich.
author: D E.

description:
I love going to this place for lunch (served M-F, Noon - 3 I think).  

They offer fresh seafood in arrangements I love (fried up or otherwise, with garlicy fries or onion rings) for a good value (about $9.22 after the state gets its sales tax on).

The guys behind the counter are plenty friendly and warm ... that helps any business (small or otherwise) to gain a following.

Stop eating burritos and chinese for a day, and head over to the San Francisco Fish Company for a tasty seafood delight!
author: Jamie W.

description: Excellent Po' Boys! Crab and Oyster
author: Erik R.

description: Great spot for lunch, or to pick up some fresh fish to take home and make for dinner. Alan and his team are there to answer your questions on just about anything you care to know about fish. Don't miss the Fat Tuesday Lunch specials for a taste of New Orleans
author: mike s.

description: Bought some wild spot prawns here and the owner told me that they were so fresh you could eat them raw. I got home and they smelled terribly fishy and had a film on them - disgusting. Will never buy seafood here again, too many other great things at the farmer's market...
author: Ashley C.

description: Dropped in for a late lunch after a morning strolling through golden gate park.  Went with the cup of chowder and smoked salmon sandwich.  Wife did the same except she went with the crab sandwich.  Both tasty and quick!
author: Erik L.

description:
I had walked past this place many times and finally went in for lunch.  They have a small menu - soups, salads, sandwiches, all seafood based.

I had the crab and shrimp salad, which was undressed crab and shrimp meat over lightly dressed mesclun.  Louis dressing was served on the side.  This salad was very fresh and delicious. 

Lunch for two with 2 lemonades was $30.00 (including tip).  They were very slow to take our order, but the food came quickly.  

Great option for a light lunch.
author: Miu M.

description:
It looks like most people have been rating this place based on the sandwiches.
I went to buy fresh mussels and walked away with mussels with a side of unease. It seemed to me that the turn around on their inventory is not very high (who goes grocery shopping there, anyways?) and I think I will go to an asian supermarket or the Mission next time. 
I also did not get the greatest service, so points off for that.

Oh, I bought some snapper while I was there, only to realize that it was imported from NEW ZEALAND. Isn't that a bit too far for sustainable local agriculture?
author: Ayse B.

description:
If you have to try anything here, get the soft shell crab poy boy sandwich... it's truly unreal!!!  The crab is fried and put in an incredibly soft yet sturdy baguette w/ some type of aioli sauce.  It's really a work of art and the flavor explodes in your mouth w/ each bite.  The food is so good here, you almost get the feeling they literally just caught the seafood and served it up.  There are tanks w/ crab and lobster, fresh fish and more all over the place.  The fries go great w/ the po boys, they have an awesome herb and salt seasoning on them. 

I also decided to get the lobster chowder in a breadbowl.  SF sourdough is perhaps one of my favorite types of bread, w/ a great crust on the outside and so incredibly moist on the inside.  I was so surprised to find the chowder not heavy at all, more light and incredibly flavorful.  The lobster meat was so plump and sweet, I almost devoured the entire bowl :)  

This is hands down one of the best places in the Ferry Building.  If you're a seafood fan, you owe it to yourself to check it out!
author: Rahul S.

description: New England clam chowder in bread bowl was good.  Fish and chips was delicious also.
author: Megan M.

description: It might look like a tourist trap, but this place is a serious fish market.  They have quality goods, at fairly high prices, but their staff are knowledgable and friendly.  They offer raw seafood and cooked dishes, and they deliver.
author: Lester B.

description: they have a seafood table out but it doesnt take credit card.  even though oysters and clams are $2 each
author: claudia y.

description: Softshell crab po' boy was gross; it's the size of a Mickey D's hamburger, but you pay $9.50.  The New England clam chowder was too salty, and others with me commented it tasted like chicken soup.  The cole slaw had way too much mayo and was sour.  It was the first and last time I'll eat here.
author: Diane A.

description: The seafood gumbo had almost no seafood with terrible taste.  The fish taco tasted better, and the fried fish was pretty good, however, it was almost impossible to eat, because the filling was really soggy, and the taco kept falling apart.  One of my tacos completely fell apart before I started eating.
author: Elena L.

description: Wow! Just got back from having the grilled Swordfish sandwich. It was soooo good. Very fresh and very delicious. I asked for the pesto aioli on the side so I could control the portioning. It was delicious! Excellent meal for about $11.
author: Sarah F.

description:
3.5 Stars (the Rating bar only allows whole star ratings)

What to I've tried:
Seafood gumbo (twice)
Soft Shell Po' Boy 

Respectable chow. Sure, it's not New Orleans, but for someone that has eaten their way through the French Quarter, this little joint in the Ferry Building will do. 

KEY: go before 11:45 or after 1:15 for faster service
author: Edward S.

description:
Terrible service. We waited at our table in the freezing cold with no one attending to us. Finally when they took our oder, we had to wait over 10 mins to just get beer and then my friend was served a cold crab pot pie.
Horrible waiter and very average food.
author: Shaheen L.

description:
The Fish & Chips are quite good even though they are not well drained. The fish they use is very delicate and the batter is close to a tempura batter. The fries seem to be dipped in their own batter which helps them be crispy.  The fried prawns on Wednesdays are great.

The Clam Chowder is not worth wasting your time on since there is no flavor in it. 

The best way to eat the food from here is right there at the small counter. If you take the fried food to go then don't go too far since it will become soggy and not as appetizing.

There is NO table service here. You order at the counter and you get it at the counter. The review complaining about the service was actually at another restaurant in the building.
author: Ray S.

description:
SF Fish Co always treats me right. I go in here at least once a week for lunch. I've sampled all sorts of things. The swordfish sandwich, so good. Crab cakes, great. The salads are simple and convenient. Lobster chowder? Yes please. I most recently tried the crab quesadilla
 and it was one of the best ways I've ever had crab.
I also go here to pick up fresh fish for when I'm feeling sassy and want to do it myself. The quality is always fresh and the folks behind the counter are so helpful and pleasant. I've yet to have a bad experience there and would highly recommend them for your lunch break, or your own culinary adventures.
author: Jessica R.

description:
In a city where there is SUCH good bread, it's disappointing when the bread bowl of a clam chowder in a bread bowl is bad.  It's even worse when it costs so dang much!

My dining companion liked her seared mahi mahi sandwich, however.  I didn't taste it, so I cannot vouch for it.
author: Marcus C.

description: We stopped in here for a really late lunch and ended up not even needing to eat dinner.  They had oysters for $1.50 that were great and then I got the soft shell crab po' boy.  That sandwich was amazing and on a soft roll from Acme.  I was plenty full after that, but I had also ordered a cup of seafood gumbo that was tasty and spicy. I would have liked a little more seafood and sausage in my gumbo, but the fact that I was able to get good tasting gumbo was enough to make me happy.  The BF had fish and chips.  I'm not sure if he liked them....he doesn't get excited about food like I do.  I thought they were great because they were big pieces of fish with just a little breading.
author: Megan C.

description: Decided to pick up some lunch from the fishery since all the other food joints were packed with long lines of tourists thanks to T-Mobile's skydiving stunt around noon. I got the ahi tuna poke, tuna salad and some seaweed salad. It wasn't cheap but the tuna salad was tasty enough on some bread I got from Acme. HOWEVER. This fishy lunch resulted in a night of intestinal turmoil and rapid weight loss. I'm no longer sure about how fresh the deli items are and it may be a while before I can gather up enough courage to try them again.
author: Trixie J.

description:
I really want to like this place, but from my professional standpoint, there are a few things I can't look past...

First... I do like the fish. Sometimes Whole Fish looks a little past prime, however I have yet to receive a hunk of flesh that has crossed the line of odor and slime (the bad kind). Which is a weird way of saying the fish is pretty fresh. The Escolar is one of my favorites here. Also live Lobster and Crab.

Also, cool pluses include Squid Ink, Whole Crawdads, Frozen Crawdad Tailmeat, and a couple of good guys behind the counter. Two of them.

Now the flipside. I too have gone in to buy and been ignored -- and would take my business elsewhere. Their loss. I was given some indignant gruff when I asked to smell a product I was going to buy. It didn't look 'right,' and so I asked. You'd think I had just insulted his madre the way he reacted. Oh well.

Sometimes the selection is limited, and sometimes they have some stuff that you just don't see without a special order.

Yes, I will continue to shop here on occasion as necessity and convenience dictate. And yes I would come back to purchase on a personal basis, too. Might I check elsewhere first.... Quite possibly.

Also, they do prepared foods, too, though I haven't indulged in any of those.

Cheers!
author: Ryan F.

description: I should have know better.  I ordered the oyster po boy. BOY WAS IT POOR!  A tiny dinner roll with a few not very well fried oysters for over $10.  I don't plan on trying it again.
author: Lalo R.

description: My wife, my brother-in-law, and I ordered from the menu on Sunday, 12/18.  The vote was unanimous: if you like small, bland, overpriced portions this your kind of place.
author: mark c.

description: I love seafood, crab, fish, lobster, oysters...you name it, i'll eat it and most likely enjoy it.  i came on a thursday for lunch, craving some good seafood.  thought i'd try this place because i was tired of all the food carts/tents outside plus i didn't want to wait in such a long line.  They had a pretty good looking menu, crabcake sandwich, award winning gumbo (they claim), many different types of fish sandiwches/po boys.  figured i'd try the swordfish sandwich with pesto aioli since it was a special, my friend ordered the crabcake sandwich.  Once we sit down and open up my lunch...i wasn't impressed with the size.  all there was in the sandwich was the fish, piece of lettuce and very little pesto, or not enough flavor in the pesto.  i could barely taste the pesto aioli.  the swordfish was good, moist, juicy, good flavor.  but there was nothing in the sandwich that screamed at me to "EAT ME".   although you aren't suppose to eat alot of swordfish in one sitting, i feel like they could have done more to it to make it look more attractive like add more garnish or more pesto aioli.  My friend wasn't impressed with the crabcake sanwich either, she said it had too much filler, not enough crab taste.  Wish i spent my $11 elsewhere, even if i did have to wait in line.  i ended up finishing my girlfriends lunch which she got from Hapa Ramen.
author: Darren W.

description: I can't really say how the food is but I did buy 3 pounds of clams for a dinner party. I was extremely disappointed when I was done cooking my clam pasta dish and 13 clams remained closed (dead) I was bummed my dish had only half the clams for my party... Good thing I had lots of wine to make up for it. They guy at the counter seemed to know the clams were old and dead and sold them to me anyway. I should have trusted my gut instinct when I first walked into the place. I would not recommend this place to buy seafood, with all the seafood in the ferry building I would go elsewhere. I emailed the company to tell them about my experience and I heard no response from them, I guess they really don't guarantee the best seafood as stated on their website.
author: Michele G.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to buy fish and seafood (the other being Sun Fat in the mission, but for different reasons). The food however is another story. This will be a hard review to write because the two aspects of SF Fish Co earn different stars in my book. First the fish: 

The thing I love about the fish and seafood here besides it's obvious freshness is the great variety and availability of certain items in their natural state. Here you can buy sea scallops in their shell with their scrumdidlyuptious roe intact. Never seen that at any where else: not Monterrey fish in Berkeley, not whole foods, no retail store of note. You could brave Chinatown but that's so much WORK. You can get whole fish like Dorade, Mullet, Sardines, Salmon and Snapper here. Giant razor clams, live and moving slow mo in their shell make an appearance. There's fresh crab, lobster, king crab and sometimes spider crabs in the tank. This is where I come when I need high quality seafood when I'm cooking! Five Stars. 

The food: recently I came in to the shop to pick up some seafood to prepare risotto with later that night. I was on my lunch from work so I decided get there to go. I ordered the fish and chips. I waited a long time (I'm not good at that!) even though the place had only me and two other customers. When my food arrived I thought the portions looked small. Back at my desk at work my fish n chips were really nothing to write home about. The kitchen committed a french fry crime in that they were soggy and not crispy at all. They needed 1 more minute in the fryer  to crisp them up to a golden brown, these were pale and soggy. That really bothers me 'cause it's so hard to mess up fries, especially for this reason. The batter on the fish was very greasy and the portion of fish small. Deep frying isn't that hard and I felt they didn't do it well. 

So...I give the retail part of the place Five Stars and the Food Two Stars. I am going to split the difference and give San Francisco Fish Co 3 Stars but emphasize that it rises to Five if you don't eat here.

Update 8/15/07: I accidently gave this 1 star, so now I've bumped it up to 3 like I meant to do.
author: Jordan N.

description: ordered a shrimp burrito special and the fish and chips.  Burrito was very good, and the fish and chips were fantastic.  Not too pricey either, and fairly large portions.  I would definitely come here again, and daydream several times to come back as well!
author: Phil J.

description: I came here for my first taste of clam chowder since moving to San Francisco, but I was also enticed by the fish and chips. The clam chowder was tasty, but I am not sure I was satisfied with the clam count. My $10 order of fish and chips came with fresh french fries and 3 nugget sized, smoking hot pieces of fried cod. They were too small. I think 4 pieces would have been fare for the price. I might come back to try the  fresh oysters and possibly some of the po-boys to compare them to New Orleans po-boys. The staff was very friendly. I will probably look elsewhere for clam chowder though.
author: Gerard C.

description:
bland fish and chips
fishy mussels 

AHHA!!! make your fish and chips out of mussels!

Davids bottom line- My genius scares me sometimes.
author: David L.

description: I love the $1.50 oyster special (oysters were from Washington today...very tasty!).  They have all the the fixings on the table for you to help yourself with but nothing beats hot sauce on raw oysters...mmM!  Also tried their New England Clam Chowder...not the greatest clam chowder but decent.  Huge pieces of clams though and they give you a roll and oyster crackers to go with it =)
author: Katelynn L.

description: I like their New England clam chowder. It had tons of clams, which I didn't expect since most clam chowders are usually full of potatoes and very few clams. The roll of bread they serve on the side was awful. I expected something better to dip in my chowder. I have to say that the service sucks though. The last time I was there, there was nobody in line except for me on a Saturday morning! I stood there forever for someone to even notice my existence and take my order.
author: Anastasia B.

description: Stumbled upon this place during lunch while roaming the Ferry Bldg.  Glad I gave it a try.  It was hard to choose which sandwich I'd go for.  Total toss up between the oyster po boy and crabcake po boy.  Went along with the oyster po boy and I was not dissapointed.  Fresh fried oysters nuzzled comfy cozy in a simply dressed roll.  It was a bit more then I expected to pay, but it was a change from the usual common sandwich in the FiDi. I would definitely go back, especially after gawking at their fresh seafood.  I was plotting dinner ideas as I was scanning their inventory.
author: Stephanie D.

description: We were wandering around shopping the market fresh fruits, flowers,veggies and some meat at prather ranch and we got hungry so we all said let's try the sf fish company. we ordered some fish and chips, they were good, not too much breading and lightly fried, the cod tasted fresh. We also had the fish tacos also very fresh. Also, the clam chowder not that good that day i hope it's better on other days but over all okay and reasonable so go for some tasty fish tacos that are seasoned nicely and good non-greasy fish'n'chips whilst walking the people go by...
author: Chris D.

description: Their sign advertising breakfast burritos has always caught my attention on crowded Saturday mornings at the farmer's market.  Finally broke down and spent $10 on the soft shell crab one.  OH MAN, am I glad I did.  It was delicious!  The perfect amount of crab and cheese and egg all wrapped up in a really light tortilla.  SO YUMMY!  Washed it down with a quad americano from Blue Bottle.  I have to be sure not to make this a habit!
author: Melissa M.

description:
After reading that SFFC had live sea urchins, I rushed over yesterday to give this a shot, arriving at ~4 pm, and picked up the last two urchins. They didn't seem to have strong signs of life, but I'm not sure how much urchins really move on their own; in any case, I was eager enough to try this that I bought them anyway. I was able to buy two for 18.50.

The first yielded about a third of a typical Japanese supermarket tray's worth of uni, and was spectacularly fresh, if mild. The second gave off a mild stink when opened, and had significantly more goop (though it also yielded much more roe). Slightly wary, I was still excited enough to try this one, as the uni still looked beautiful and was more orange - I figured that the flavor would have been stronger. It tasted of rot. I dumped it immediately.

After the effort involved in opening them and in cleaning the sink afterwards, and considering the price paid, I was sorely disappointed after being assured at the store that the urchins were well and alive. I'll give catalina offshore products a shot at $5 a pop next time, and will not be returning to the SFFC.
author: Will T.

description: I had the blackened catfish sandwich.  The fish and the bread were both very fresh.  Absolutely zero creativity so only 4 stars.
author: Adam B.

description:
a wonderful array of fresh seafood to choose from and little seafood salads of sorts...

and delicious lobster chowder~

i really liked that lobster chowder...mmmmmm~
author: phillip w.

description: I have gone here a few times with the hubby though haven't gotten around to reviewing it so may as do it now. Aside from the fact that this is one of my favorite parts of the city, especially to just come out and distress while catching the nice water front views and taking a nice stroll with friends or by myself. We came upon this little fishy company while shopping at the farmers market on a Saturday and felt like some seafood. My hubby loves fish and chips so we decided to order than while I had gotten some fish sandwich. I didn't like my fish sandwich too much but we both loved the fish and chips they serve here along with the tartar sauce. Usually it's better to come here on a less crowded day like a weekday since there is very little seating and you end up having to stand and the prices are not really cheap but not ridiculous either. The wait is not too slow but also not quick, and sometimes there can be long lines. Overall, one of the best fish and chip places we've tried in the city.
author: Petra S.

description: I had the lobster bisque today.  It was bland.  I put some vineagre in it, tasted better.  My main gripe is complete lack of lobster meat in the bisque.  I had a chunk of cornstarch I thought was lobster.
author: M K.

description: It's in the ferry building which is very touristy so of course, it's a bit overpriced. But I had the oyster po' boy and it was delicious. Portion is a bit small for $9 but the sandwich was filled with fresh oyster which you could really taste. But they wash it cleanly and fry it so you don't taste too much brine. The slaw they give you isn't too bad either.
author: James L.

description: THE best oysters in the Ferry Building (and yes I've been to Hog Island..)! They are soo much bigger and tastier. Raw osyters are fantastic but I was also happy to be able to buy a bag of 20 and bring them home to BBQ. The perfect dinner! :D
author: Julia T.

description:
the place looks pretty plain, with a few chairs and tables in what looks to be your average, run-of-the-mill fish department.

however, the staff is incredibly knowledgeable in their trade, and they make a pretty damned good crabcake sandwich, at a good price. 

so, you get the food quality from the type of fishers often seen in movies such as "the perfect storm" without the snobbishness usually associated with anything in or bordering the financial district.

take it outside and enjoy the view, all the idiots who work in the high-rise buildings  forget that the piers are public walkways.

it's safe to say that i haven't had this much fun eating seafood since one of the many apples of my eye was showing me around the long beach aquarium, after which we headed directly across the street to, where else, Bubba Gump's.

[i consider that my discovery channel buffet, but i digress]
author: Charles C.

description: I really like the swordfish sandwich with aioli as well as their fish and chips. The only downside is that they stop serving food after 3 even though they are still open. Also, seating is extremely limited but it seems like people don't eat there much so I haven't had a problem so far during the weekends.
author: Diane M.

description: Came here for lunch and had their fish and chips.  It was by far the best Fish & Chips I have ever had!!!  Amazingly light crust and perfect portion for lunch.  This is all I have tried at this spot so far, but I really like the atmosphere and would definitely come back again.
author: km k.

description:
the three stars are for the friendly staff on a busy saturday farmer's market.

the food- raw oysters didn't look appetizing by 1pm so went for the tuna sandwhich, which unfortunately was (1) well done and (2) slathered in sooo much mayo. Where's the freshness?
author: Tom L.

description: A fairly good place to satisfy that seafood craving. I like the posters on the walls. I had the Steamed Shellfish. I thought the $10 was fair for the prawns, clams, mussels, and piece of bread. It was good, but a little too salty. I also didn't find the portion filling enough. Not a whole lot of seating and service was a little slow.
author: summer k.

description: Stopped in for a quick bite - the oyster po' boy was tasty and the fries were good, crab cake sandwich was so-so because it was a little greasy and didn't have much flavor. Their bread was only ok.  My favorite part of the meal was the cold slaw, which was definitely yummy.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
The food is great.  If I was just rating that, it would be 5 stars.  The lobster bisque is *incredible*.  But the place is tiny, there is no where to sit, and prices are quite high (aside from the soups).

No matter, I'm sure I'll be back.  There is a lack of good inexpensive food in the financial district, so this fits the bill quite nicely sometimes.
author: Jeff W.

description: This place looked good and it wasn't just oysters on the menu.  I did the tuna burger which was tasty and the BF had the shrmp and chips but  it was a small basket of food, not even a decent pile of fries.  At some point they brought out oysters on ice where you can just buy individual oysters.  At $2 each seemed high but they were super delicious until the last one, thought I was going to hurl right there.
author: Brian H.

description: Terrible service! Doesn't even know how to void a transaction. Food is ready but won't even serve u! Terrible!!!!
author: E C.

description: The fish is great, but I liked them better in Rockridge. Go back home; your relplacements are mean!
author: Rene D.

description: I was very pleasently surprised to find this place at the Ferry Market!  We bought DELICIOUSLY FRESH fish (it's amazing... you can taste the difference).  Highly recommend it!
author: Mrs. G.

description: Went here for a quick lunch. I had the swordfish sandwich with aoli. The fish was good but the aoli was a little off. I think it was mayonnaise. This is a great place for a quick lunch. They have a good selection of fish.
author: Ginny M.

description: We went on Dec. 26th, 2007.  The cashier was rude and the food took forever to be ready. The fish and chips were greasy and there wasn't enough fish.  We felt disgusting and greased up the entire day.  It ruined our appetite for dinner.
author: Kay By The Bay -.

description: Enjoyable oysters for $1.50/each.  They also have some good louie salads, pasta salads with seafood, poke, etc.  It's worth it to stop by and check it out if you want a light summery lunch.  Or if you want a heavier meal as well, since they do have the requisite fried seafood items like fish and chips and crab cakes.
author: Kalista W.

description: For being super hungry, I thought this place was going to be out of this world, but it fell a tad short.  Maybe I got the wrong thing but the crab quesadilla was really good but not super duper (which I am reserving my 5 stars for).  By far the best aspect of the joint is that there are prime people watching seats that face outwards.  Side note - the guy that works there will give you an extra cup of chowder if you order it in the bread bowl, and proceed to call it juice because the bread soaks it up faster than you can consume it.  Fish juice!  Love it. LOL.
author: Yve T.

description: And I got to wonder, is there another place? There is no wait staff here and they dont serve alcohol. I think this place is getting some bad pub from teh people who have been served by some other place posing as the SFFC
author: Adam L.

description: With the office near the ferry bldg, I've been trying the different places there.  Yesterday, I opted to go off the reservation from my general haunts and hit the SF Fish Company for the first time.  Ordered the crab cake sandwich which comes with a remoulade sauce.  It totally *rocked* my world!  Didn't have high expectations, just expected something plain, but was instead blown away by this flavor jubilee.  Almost went back today for another.  Definitely makes it into one of my weekly lunch spots from here on.
author: P W.

description:
Hands down the worst customer service I have encountered in the San Francisco food world. Got the gumbo to go-which turned out to be a container of grease seemingly skimmed off the top of the gumbo vat-absolutely no ingredient present but grease-disgusting. I took the time out of my busy day & returned to the scene of the culinary crime to inform them of their unnacceptable product-always a pet peeve of mine-to have to return back when they get the order wrong. Ok, so maybe I could have been more subtle and a tad less irked when I told the manager that they had provided me w/an unwanted bowl of grease-but his response was off the charts uncalled for-kicked me out of the store-tried to kick me out of the ferry building & seemed to  threaten physical violence on my person. All I wanted was an acknowledgement that they could have quality controlled somewhat better & they could have shown a bit of remorse. Shame on you.
What a zero.
I will never return to this horrible mannerless greasepit.
author: jeremy g.

description: i was in a hurry today, so i just grabbed a cold sandwich from the fridge section to go.  i got a crab salad sandwich, which was a bit pricey at $9.50.  for the same price, you could get a seared tuna sandwich, a grilled fish (mahi mahi, swordfish, etc), fish tacos, or a myriad of other grilled/fried goodies.  i will be back to try their other hot food, which looked yummy, especially the fish and chips!
author: Helen T.

description: I always stop here whenever I'm in the city. Great chowder and their fish and chips are never too greasy. Staff is always friendly and more than willing to give you recommendations.  Haven't been disappointed with a meal from here yet.
author: Travis V.

description: I've been here at least three times... once as referred by their neighbours across the street-- the heavenly Prather Ranch Boys.  What has me laughing are all of the reviews about the slow/bad service-- have any of these reviewers ever been to New England?  The Cape?  Faneuil Hall? Fisherman's Wharf, even?  Seafood stands are not about pleasantries-- not about nicey-nice.  Seafood stands the world over are about fresh fish, seafood, authenticity and flavour which these guys have.  I've bought live crab and lobster here-- all good, shrimp salad, sandwiches-- all tasty.  However, I would wonder about some advice they gave me about keeping lobster more than a few days, and I haven't tried the clam chowder which I use to gauge seafood respectability.  The prices are high cause of the ferry building loc so, really, get over it, and if you're from the East like me and like your talk a bit salty, there's nothing with the service either.  Go, Yankees!
author: E L.

description: I think a lot of reviewers have this place mixed up with the other seafood/fish place in the Ferry Bldg (this place doesn't shuck oysters).  I like this place simply because it is almost the only place close to my work where I can get fish.  I tried some of their cooked entrees but feel they are overpriced (for the tourist trade) and nothing very special.  I do like the prepared salads since I can get my crab louis fix almost year 'round (and I'm willing to pay the $10--which is too high but when you've gotta have it and there's no where else to go that's quick...).  I also got some Hawaii poke seasonings for my brother (I'm hoping he'll take the hint and make poke at some point for me).  And they sometimes have fresh mackerel which I am finding hard to find elsewhere.  I love looking at their fish and sometimes even buy some (but having to keep it in the work refrig until I can go home gets to be a project since the frig is overloaded already).  The guys always are very nice and patient.  Prices tend to be slightly higher then at my regular fish store but we're in the FiDi so I expected that.  Yeh, and they had a very very leggy [Alaskan Snow?] crab live in the tank--I've never seen one alive (can you say War of the Worlds?).
author: Kai T.
